Who is to say how you would feel if this happened to you,and your family......?????Read this story...... I was familiar with it happening due to reading about it in Newsweek, & Rolling Stone many years ago, but if you were not aware of this situation at all......you may find yourself just as angry and just as whacked out over the whole chaotic mess......Enjoy! As they say....truth is stranger then fiction.......Gary

Henrietta Lacks develops cervical cancer is the 1950's, goes into Johns Hopkins Hospital and after a couple of horrific treatments passes away. Her cells are another story, they continued to live on after biopsies of her cancerous tissue was taken without her permission or her family's knowledge and grown in labs to be shipped around the world to test diseases, develop gene therapy, and ultimately change the world. All the while, her children and family had no idea that this was happening, and they struggle to come to terms with what it means to have immortal cells, while the family can barely afford medical treatment.Rebecca Skloot takes a nearly impossible task of researching something that was breaking at the time, and challenges human rights to our own tissue and most importantly how client consent has changed over the past couple of decades. Fascinating story merging the lines of racial and gender discrimination, while also facing class struggles. In my opinion, this book should be required reading.

The story behind the infamous "HeLa" cells are interesting to most scientists, as most of us have either worked with them, read endless research articles/journals utilizing them, and know about their contributions to science and/or medicine, among many more things. This immortal cell line was derived from Mrs. Lacks' cervical tissue, which became cancerous after she was infected with HPV. She recieved treatment for cervical canver at Johns Hopkins University, known at this time period for treating black patients. Though I don't know how her race/ethnicity/social status affected her personal treatment at the hospital, the actual medical treatment for her condition was unbiased and the normal protocol for any one with the condition. During this time period, research physicians, or physicians who were interetsed in biomedical research were striving to culture an immortal cell line, which has enormous applications and implications in biomedical research. The physicians, with the help of other scientists and technicians, were able to create a cell line that had greatly sought-after conditions for the purposes of biomedical research, inlcuding immortalization and ease of growth in culture. The use of her cells greatly impacted the field of biomedical research, and the cultivation and use of the HeLA cell line contributed to the establishment of the first Polio vaccine, cancer research, and countless other types of research where the characteristics of the HeLa cell line offer great advatange and resource for pusuit of scientific knowledge. My review of this book has nothing to do with the contributions her cells have made to the scientific community. The physicians at the time did take her cells and culture them without her consent, but that was standard protocol at the time, and she was not isolated for that purpose. We have all contributed from the use of her cells, therefore, it is hypocritical to be critical of the use of them.Despite a major attempt to create a "boogey-man" portrait of the physicians/scientists that worked with her cells, none of them were awarded financially for establishing the HeLa cell line. The author tries to create an image of a poor black woman who was robbed of her cells without consent and not awarded the enormous monentary prize for their use, but the truth is, this was standard procedure at that time period,and her cells just happened to actually work for that purpose. I was very interested to learn more about Mrs. Lacks in this book. What made this book impossible to read was the author. She hardly writes more than a few pages about Mrs. Lacks. She mostly wrote a biography detailing her attempts at finding information, without providing anything insightful about the actual woman it was supposed to be about, Mrs. Lacks. Most of the book is about her relatives and their immense anger and resentment about not being compensated for the use of Mrs. Lacks' cells. I don't really give a shit about that. A lot of shitty things happen to people in this world, this wasn't in any way the worst, and that would have made a decent book if that was what the book was supposed to be about. This book was so boring, I didn't even finish it.

This book has been around for a while now, so most people know the basis. Rebecca Skloot tells the story here of Henrietta Lacks, the poor black woman who died of cervical cancer in 1951. Why do we care about Henrietta Lacks? Quite simply, her cells, which were taken without her knowledge or consent, became known as HeLa cells. Now does it sound familiar? HeLa cells have been around for a while, recognizable to many for their importance in developing the polio vaccine and gene mapping. HeLa cells have survived and grown since 1951.But Skloot recognized there was more to the science than just the letters HeLa. She set out to uncover the truth about the person behind the abbreviation. With the help of members of Lacks's family, Skloot spent about a decade on this book. She visited the now-defunct Clover, where Lacks grew up, she took Henrietta's daughter, Deborah, to the hospital where her sister, Elsie, was put away as an "imbecile" and where she died under suspicious circumstances. Deborah, who was four when Henrietta died, was just as committed to finding out the full story about her family as Skloot was.The book bounces around in time, from the 40s and 50s as Skloot detailed Henrietta's life and illness, to "present day" of 2009 when the book was published. Skloot's own journey with her research began in the late 90s. She got married and divorced during the writing of this book. She knew Henrietta Lacks was unknown by the public, even though her cells had been such a vital part of medicine and science for decades.The heartbreaking part about this real-life story is that Henrietta's descendants and family knew nothing about the HeLa cells themselves. They were never given any real explanation about the cells, nor were they compensated in any way. The book brings to light a lot of issues, from social to ethical. Most impressive is the concept that all tissue in and on your body belongs to you while it's attached to you, but as soon as it's removed from you, it's not longer "yours". You have no rights over it. It can be researched and sold and re-sold and modified and studies. You get no say in whether you want studies on pieces of your body to go towards the cure for cancer or for the creation of atomic bombs or other devices of mass destruction.Years ago I had a cyst removed. Thinking of a Margaret Atwood story, I asked my surgeon (and every subsequent tech and anesthesiologist whom I met prior to surgery) if I could keep my cyst once they excised it. After their initial responses of "Ew, WHY?" they told me that would not, could not, should not ever be available to me. "But it's MINE" I tried to argue. They claimed liability, and disease (not that I had a disease, but it's jut not sanitary). None of them had read the Atwood story I was referencing, but if they had, they would have been even more adamant that I should be allowed nowhere near the cyst once it had been removed.I've thought about the same thing during a breast biopsy and then more recently, when they removed my thyroid. What are they going to do with it? What I really would like, more than being able to keep these things that have been pulled from my body over the years, is frequent updates about the road my tissues have traveled. Remember in the 90s the popularity of things like adopting a star, or a whale, or a polar bear. You'd get a picture in the mail for the low-cost of whatever, and then a few updates throughout the year about where your whale is and how it is faring.That's what I want with the tissues that have been taken from me. Just a postcard with a picture of what they're doing with my tissues, a little update that says "ElPa cell was just sold to Norway for the price of 8 million where they will study the effects of cigarette smoking on this tissue taken from your breast in the early 2000s!"As Skloot spent more time with the Lacks family, she became almost a member of the family herself. After the initial periods of suspicion and caution, Skloot was embraced and was called for all the important family births and deaths and other major life experiences. From a personal storytelling point of view, I found that touching, though it wasn't exactly a necessary part of the main story.I suppose really it means that HeLa (Henrietta Lacks) is a part of everyone, brings us all together. She continues to live, and while her family will never see any portion of the proceeds and still have no say over their mother's cells, there's some satisfaction that can be derived from how common the name Henrietta Lacks is now. The woman behind the cells should never be forgotten. Her contributions (that she didn't even know she was making) should be told. She was more than just the abbreviations HeLa.I know everyone has read this book already by this point, but it came up in my little world because I'm now on the Common Reader Committee at the university where I work. At the first meeting, it became obvious that very few of us are actually readers (one went so far as to say he doesn't like to read, which begs the question as to why he was even there). This book was one of my recommendations, even though I hadn't read it yet. My boss read the first six chapters and felt that it would cover a lot of the bases that our university likes to cover, and would appeal to the three main colleges very well by dealing with social justice issues, science and medicine, legality, ethics, and health and wellness.Now that I've read this book on my own I can go back to our meeting next week and say, holy shit guys, this book really does cover ALL the bases. The idea is this would be a book that everyone could read - every student, staff, and faculty member. While the story meanders a bit and gets a bit dry in other places, I think ultimately the story of Henrietta Lacks and her cells will appeal to all readers in the university.But if I hear one more time from anyone "But are they mature enough for it" I will scream. College students aren't quite as dumb as everyone likes to think they are. Maybe they're lazy, but cheese and rice, I'm not going to dumb down the Common Reader in concerns that students won't be able to read a book anymore.Plus there's an HBO movie coming out next month based on this book, so if just reading a book isn't incentive enough, maybe Oprah will be.(My other top contenders would be The Handmaid's Tale and March: Book One. Though some on the committee thinks if we give a graphic novel to college students they will think we're giving them "cartoons" to read and there may be an uprising. It's fascinating to me how little faculty and staff know the students at their own university. To be fair, those who suggest an uprising are also the ones who don't read, and they claim not to know how to read a graphic novel. Someone asked "Do you start at the front or the back?" conflating graphic novels with manga, I believe. This committee will be a long road for me. Someone just put me in charge already.)

It reads like good crime fiction. It chronicles the life of the woman whose cancerous tissue became the first tissue in history which could be successfully grown as culture and used in various, and countless, experiments from vaccine research to cloning. Her tissue was so successful in fact that it became virtually immortal, surviving in various environments and proliferating at prodigious rates. Yet, very little was known about the woman herself, her life, her family, her history, and this is what Skloot set out to uncover. What she found out is absolutely stunning from the point of medical ethics, American history and American healthcare. Fascinating. Highly recommended.
A book for all Seasons: nonfiction to learn from

This book was phenomenal in more ways than one. I knew a little bit about Henrietta Lacks, but I was definitely not aware of the extent to which her family was affected by the use of her sells in modern day biology. It broke my heart to see how her family, deeply rooted in religious beliefs, was broken because they felt as though Henrietta's soul resided in those cells. I have my own personal opinions about the entire concept of doctors taking medical waste for their own advantages. Nevertheless, what I can say about this issue is that it is stories such as the Tuskegee Experiment and the use of Henrietta's cells that have ultimately made the black community hesitant about wanting to go to doctors. I plan to do more research on this topic and it may be a project that I throw myself into. Hopefully I can find more text that really delves into the black community's experience with the medical field. This really opened my eyes to a lot of issues related to the medical field/industry and I can't wait to read more.

Ah, the all-important and oh-so-confusing topic of bioethics! I like a book that makes me think, just as I did when I was a college student. There's a fine line between what is ethically/morally "right" and that which infringes on a person's own being and that person's (or family of said person) rights to his/her cells. There are never any correct answers or final conclusions in the world of bioethics...it's an ongoing dispute but one that really caused me to question my own decisions and how they are interpreted.

The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks is required reading for pharmaceutical students at a nearby Oklahoma University where a friend of my daughter goes to college. She told me about this book over Christmas. I can see why it’s required reading. I’m glad it is and I hope it is for medical and research students everywhere.It tells the story of an African American woman, Henrietta Lacks, who went to Johns Hopkins in 1951 for treatment for cervical cancer. Some cancerous cells were removed from her body. This much she knew. The cells were also saved, cultured, and reproduced—without her knowledge or consent—as was common practice at the time. What makes this an amazing story is that Henrietta’s cells have never died from that day until the present, hence the title. They continue to grow and reproduce at a phenomenal rate. They currently exist in laboratories, hospitals and warehouses all over the world; have been used in almost every form of scientific research from the 50’s until now; have gone to space; have been contaminated and caused contamination. The scientific and medical communities owe untold debt to the cells it calls HeLa and yet not one dime of compensation, even in terms of discounted medical care or health insurance has ever been received by any of Henrietta’s numerous descendants. Interestingly enough, they aren’t looking for anything in that way. Now isn’t that refreshing? Rather, in spite of all they have suffered—and indeed this is a book about pain—their focal interest throughout was in finding out what happened to their mother since she died so young, gaining recognition for her and learning what happened to Henrietta’s oldest daughter who died in a ‘hospital for the negro insane’, which was 1950’s terminology.  The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks crosses many disciplines and for that reason I expect scientists might skim the vignettes about Henrietta’s children, while those who prefer human interest could find themselves avoiding the technical sections. Virginia Woolf’s Common Readers, however, will positively adore this book! It has everything they look for in the written word. Not only what was just mentioned, but also: the complexities and importance of the ‘tissue issue’, what are the medical, legal, ethical, and other parameters for tissue gathering, storage, research, usage, and compensation. And I commend the author, Rebecca Skloot, a self-proclaimed non-believer for her sensitive handling of the many stressed and stressful events, issues and personalities she encountered concerning matters of faith, morals, and religion.  A very important book to read!  Here is a rather long but fascinating 1998 BBC documentary about Henrietta Lacks and HeLa.  Here is an article which gives some more current info about the Lacks family and the issue of privacy v. tissue donation.

Henrietta Lacks, a young African-American mother of five children, died in Baltimore in 1951 from a highly aggressive form of cervical cancer—but more than fifty years after her death, part of her lives on in the form of HeLa, a cell line cultivated from a tissue sample of hers which played a key role in several major scientific and medical breakthroughs. Skloot's book tells Lacks' story, partly to pay tribute to a woman who was forgotten by all but her family for many years despite her importance to medicine; partly in order to examine the complex attendant issues of medical ethics, race and class. Skloot's writing is fluid and accessible, and I learned some things which were shocking though not surprising to me (see the organ retention scandal which broke in Ireland a few years ago). That said, I would have liked for a stronger focus on the ethics and the science aspect of the novel and less on the lives of Lacks' children and other relatives. Skloot's focus on them and on some of the more unpalatable aspects of their lives felt quite voyeuristic to me at points, recounted not because Skloot wanted to examine the effects of the vicious cycle of poverty on people's lives but because it would inject more drama into the book. The author talks at length about the less-than-pure motivations of those who had previously profited from Lacks' cells, and their refusal to compensate Lacks' family in any way, about how she was financing her research with credit cards and student loans—and yet her end-goal was always to acquire a book deal, and her account of her relentless attempts to get in touch with members of the Lacks family made me highly uncomfortable. Much of the latter half of the book dealt with the relationship between Skloot and Deborah, Henrietta Lacks' youngest daughter—again, uncomfortable to read about at several points, and not especially relevant to the book's main thrust. Overall, an interesting read, but I feel that The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks could easily have been edited down to half its length—and focused more on Henrietta because of it.

it's as if the writer wanted the story the way i would want it, and self-observes the arc of her own education the way i would, so the emotional style resonated at a profound level: a combination of passion, humility & fearlessness that makes me trust the her completely, that makes me grateful she is the person who chose this story - or that it chose her.& then there's the story - the science. the race & class issues, the muck of medical ethics before patients were real people and blackfolk were real patients... that's the warp. The weft is the story of a friendship between two women meeting each other on the edge of both their worlds, brought there by Henrietta: her immortality is not simply a series of cells.the narrators are excellent. the pacing is a tiny bit slow, but that works for the direct quotes - and hearing voices in dialect anchors the story in time and place. The voices in this story - the amount of quoted text & speech- keep this story very immediate - with the feel of a good documentary or good fiction.a joy.

I had heard so much about this book and was so excited to read it . . . but there's not much to read. I tell you the premise, and that's the book. It just keeps doubling over itself to tell you the same science, the same sad story of the people it affected, and nothing ever really happens. People say things like "hold on, are you ready for this?" and then nothing happens. It's the same information over and over. So I'm going to spoil the whole book for you; Henrietta Lacks was a poor syphilitic black woman who married her cousin, had a bunch of kids, and died very young of an aggressive cancer, the cells of which doctors took samples of without asking and then developed into the first 'immortal' cell line, which went on to be used by scientist and doctors around the world. Her descendants are plagued by poverty and bad health. That's it. Now imagine me telling you different versions of that over and over while I also tell you about how I'm researching and writing about it, dealing with this difficult and suspicious relatives. That's the book.

Very well written book that talks about race,science,and issues relating to ethics. Henrietta Lacks was a poor black women who cells were taken without her consent and used by many scientists to develop vaccines,cloning, and many more things. Unfortunately her family was very poor and never received any money from her cells being used.They had many health problems and could not afford health insurance and died young as a result. I learned a lot of interesting facts while reading this book.
The latest in my "should've read a long time ago" project did not disappoint.

Its a very important story, its unique in its format of that the cells of Henrietta lacks are doing and how it seems that even today nobody understand why or how those cells are even still alive, BUT sadly the actual story of doctors doing something without permission is NOT a unique one, since sadly there are still today patients being used without their knowledge -as it is even stated in the book itself. And i think that especially that is something that should be taking away from this book: This story is important and interesting, but so far not much has changed in the medical field so that this type of thing does not continues to happen without permission from the patients themselves. This book does point out quiet a lot of positive things that happened because and with cells and how it could have never happened without them. Some horrendous things, some wonderful things where achieved thanks to those cells and with that thanks to Henrietta Lacks. And i am defiantly one of the first people to point out that medical advances are necessary and that we still have way to little knowledge and actual solutions for way to man illnesses! But i think that this book also points out two very important things and drives them home quiet nicely: 1. Human tissue was once part of a person!We all should respect that. Yes its important that a lot of different science fields have access to tissue samples. But its also important to remember the people that gave those samples. Be it willingly, unwillingly, during life or after their death, it was once part of a living breathing person! I think a lot of us prefer to ignore that, or try to forget it and i think that is defiantly one thing we all should work on always remembering when we take any kind of medicine without a second thought! 2. there are lot of loopholes legally that should be worked on!All this talk of "technically it wasn't required" in this book just made me want to shake someone! What it comes down to in very basic forms -especially in regards of this specific book and the story it tells- is that everyone should be asking for permission. Doctors and scientists should explain in understandable terms what they want and why it could be helpful and i am pretty sure that a lot of people -especially those with illnesses!- will be more than willing to hand out tissue samples for further use! No need to just take them without asking! So why do it?Which brings it all back to the first point: lets not forget all those "samples" actually come from someone that is not just there to be a lab-rat!Now the one "negative" thing of this book is that i personally didn't really like how the Skloot wrote this book. Some sections felt as if she wanted to get that particular part of the story told and done with as fast as possible and shoved a lot of details and information into a pretty small section and number of pages. And than sometimes she would go on and on about some things for endless number of pages that i personally felt that it wasn't necessary to go on about it for that long. To say it short it is not he best nonfiction writing i have read. BUT its also far from the worst. Its very readable and yes it could have been kept a little shorter, but all in all it was done pretty well in the writing department. of course that is completely personal and some of the reviews i read LOVED the writing, so clearly that part is debatable.If you are interested in this book, defiantly give it a try. If you are going into a scientific field? Defiantly read this!

A book like this makes me realize how important education in general and particularly science education is. Today’s science is yesterday’s magic—for those who don’t understand science, it can seem like very frightening black magic. The story of Henrietta Lacks explores the intersection between science, research, education, capitalism, civil rights, and consent.The major question implicit in this book is whether we have any claim to our own cells after they have been removed from our bodies. Is it ethical to take “discarded” cells—those left over after medical procedures—and do research from them and potentially make money from either the cells or the research. This issue gets us down somewhere in our irrational subconscious—after all, we all “know” enough about voodoo and black magic to know that curses require hair, nail clippings, blood, or other bodily secretions in order to be effective. In many ways, the story of the HeLa cell line traces the history of medical research in the US (and to some extent, other countries), evolving from the exploitation of vulnerable people towards the concept of informed consent. It also traces the history of an African American family, liberated from slavery, but not from poverty and deprivation. The current distrust of science has some real roots in situations like these, where people were used without their knowledge for experimental purposes. But the lack of scientific literacy in the general population helps with the proliferation of conspiracy theories and the prevalence of medical quackery. Witness all the “miracle cures” that people buy into. One older lady that I used to work with was always pouring money into some miracle weight loss scheme or another—it didn’t seem to occur to her that if the method actually worked, it would be front page news on Time magazine, not some obscure ad in the back of a newspaper.We have to seriously question ourselves and our politicians about the quality of our educational systems. Are they being funded? Do we have enough teachers? Can poor children hope to get education equal to that of rich children?As my grandfather used to say, no education is wasted.

For a non-fiction book about science, this book is pretty interesting. Chapters about genes, cloning and cancer are juxtaposed with chapters about Henrietta's personal life and about the author's interactions with the Lacks family. I think this book would scare a lot of people about how privacy is dealt with as a legal issue in the medical community. The book is about Henrietta Lacks - a woman whose cells live on and on to be experimented with, cloned, put into space, blown up, used to make human-animal and human-plant hybrids, etc. The point of the book is that these cells were taken from her without her knowledge or consent. Today, no one in her family can afford medical care, even though their mother/grandmother's cells are stored by the billions in laboratories around the world. This brings up many interesting points in debates about what rights the medical community has to do procedures 'for the benefit of humankind' vs. the rights of the individual and patient. Do your cells and tissues belong to you? Do they still belong to you, even when removed from your body? It is surprising how fuzzy the laws still are on this issue. The book also touches a little bit on racism - Henrietta was black, and the doctors who took and distributed her cells were white. But racism isn't the main focus. I found this book fascinating - and cell research isn't really my forte. I recommend this book, even to people who generally don't read or like non-fiction.

I read this book back in 2013 just before I joined Goodreads. I found my review on Audible and decided to add it to Goodreads for my records.This is a well written non-fiction book that provides back ground information about unfair treatment of minorities by medical research. Cassandra Campbell and Bahni Turpin did a great job with the narration of the book. The story of Henrietta Lacks and her family is interesting and the discovery and care of the Hi La cells. One major item about the family is the lack of education that played a major role in their understanding and ability to control the situation. The book accomplishes its goal of promoting proper documentation of biological tissue research. It raises the question of ownership of our own tissues and whether or not we have proprietary rights to our bodies in situ or in vitro. This question needs to be answered NOW not in the future. The other teaching of the book was how important education is to each individual. This is an absolute must read book for everyone on this planet.

This was definitely much more than just your average popular science book. Never have a I read a non-fiction book that is so multi-faceted - science, superstition, ethics, family troubles, violence, estrangement, racism - what a cocktail! Full review soon.
Holy shit this book is awesome.

I blew through this fascinating audiobook, practically manufacturing housework to do so that I'd have an excuse to plug myself in (okay, that's a bit of an exaggeration; there was plenty of housework to do without my having to manufacture any). I would recommend this book to just about anyone seeking a great read -- even if you're usually more of a fiction person, this non-fiction book offers plenty of interesting characters and storylines as well as being informative and provocative in the way of non-fiction.Did you know that much of medical research (and the benefits we derive every day, including many routine vaccines and medications we take for granted) is dependent on a culture of human cells that continue to live and reproduce even after their original owner died in 1951? Well, I didn't. And I wouldn't have thought that this factoid would interest me particularly, not being much of a science person myself. But somehow, Rebecca Skloot was able to make the dynamics surrounding these cells not only comprehensible to me but intriguing (no small feat). Even more intriguing, though, was the story of the late human being behind these cells, Henrietta Lacks, who never knew that her cells had been taken for research. Henrietta's surviving children, tragically losing their mother at a young age to cervical cancer and raised in a poor and abusive environment, only learned about this later in life and never saw a penny of the proceeds."The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks" contains several stories. There is the story of Henrietta, a poor young African American woman with incurable cervical cancer, and of her children struggling to grow up without her after her early death. There is the story of the doctor who decided to slice off pieces of her tumor just prior to her death without asking or even informing her, who then discovered that these cancerous cells were immortal. There is the story of the cells, which began to be mass-produced and distributed to researchers for a wide variety of interesting and often ground-breaking experiments. And there is the story of Rebecca Skloot, a journalist who was persistent and dogged in her efforts to win Henrietta's family's reluctant trust (after they had been duped by others attempting to capitalize on Henrietta) so that she could learn and tell their story.Henrietta's adult children in this book are colorful characters with their own stories who overcame some difficult situations, some more successfully than others. We also meet different doctors and researchers -- while some prove to be profiteers, others are truly dedicated to science for its own sake. The doctor who originally took Henrietta's tumor for research without her knowledge fell into the latter category, which is part of what makes this a three-dimensional book rather than a simplistic polemic. A product of his times, this 1950s doctor was less sensitive to the medical and research ethics which have since received more attention, particularly when it came to a poor African-American woman. Should you care if someone uses your body tissues for medical research without your consent? Before I began reading this book, my thought was, why the heck would I care? Assuming that these tissues need to be removed in any case, why not use them to do some good for science and for mankind? But Rebecca offers some anecdotes which complicate this question, and the irony running throughout the book is that Henrietta's descendants cannot afford decent medical care, even as the entire medical profession benefits from Henrietta's unwittingly donated cells.Even if you think you're not a science person, even if you think you're not a non-fiction person, I would recommend checking this book out.

On the threshold between medicine and ethics.This book talks about ethical and legal conflicts, historically raised by the discovery of immortal cells that changed medicine and patients life's for the better. It‘s an astonishing story you probably didn‘t hear about before:In 1951 a colored poor woman named Henrietta Lacks walked into the Hopkins University, where a doctor extracted cells from her large cervix tumor, that killed her briefly after. But as they discovered in the laboratory, those were anything but normal cells, but the first immortal human cells grown in culture. They are still alive today and were replicated to millions and spread to laboratories all over the world, though Lacks has been dead for more than sixty years. They called them HeLa cells and they were vital for developing the polio vaccine; uncovered secrets of cancer, viruses, and the atom bomb’s effects; helped lead to important advances like in vitro fertilization, cloning, and gene mapping; and have been bought and sold by the billions. What interested me the most was the scientific and legal part of that book. Ultimately it‘s a question of property and if we have the right on our cells, once they leave our body, particularly if we don‘t know about it.First there is the problem with uninformed consent. Henrietta did not provide informed consent for her cells to be used, she didn‘t have knowledge. Beyond that people were later unknowingly injected with her tumor cells, for the purpose of medical research. The same was performed on healthy prisoners with their knowledge, though their free consent seems to be questionable. They developed tumors, sometimes killing them. Furthermore her autopsy report was later published in the book of a journalist, the family didn‘t knew about and didn‘t want to see published. The question is the violation of privacy rights.The second problem are genetic rights/non-rights. Her family (whose DNA also links to those cells) did not learn of the implications of her tissue sample until years later, and didn‘t fully approve of it‘s usage A big focus also are patents and profits for biologic material.Henrietta and her family were very poor and didn’t even have health insurance. They received zero profits, while her cells sell for multiple-millions until today.Very shocking are also racism claims. Because the cells were discovered in the 50, making public that white people were treated with cell stems of a black woman would have had a major impact. Additionally implications are made, that colored people were categorically abused, abducted, purposely infected and killed to perform medical experiments. The biographical nature of the book ensures the reader does not separate the science and ethics from the family. These are not abstract questions, impacts and implications, but actual, valuable people and historic events.What I didn’t like just as much though, is how the story is told at times, jumping between characters and writing styles; sometimes loosing the silver lining. The writing is very simple and doesn’t at all feel factual. As a non fiction fan, I miss that at times but I guess that others appreciate it even more. It reads a lot like a novel, particularly since a lot of content is told through conversations. In conclusion a super interesting story I won’t forget quickly!

What a wonderful book! It describes the life of Henrietta Lacks and her family, the origin of the HeLa cell line (the first human immortal cell line), the research conducted with these cells, and also the author’s research and interviews in unfolding this story.“I’ve tried to imagine how she’d feel knowing that her cells went up in the first space missions to see what would happen to human cells in zero gravity, or that they helped with some of the most important advances in medicine: the polio vaccine, chemotherapy, cloning, gene mapping, in vitro fertilization. I’m pretty sure that she—like most of us—would be shocked to hear that there are trillions more of her cells growing in laboratories now than there ever were in her body.”

Can't wait to recommend this book to my bookclub. It will make for a fabulous discussion. This book can satisfy several audiences on several different levels. The technical information about the science of cells is fascinating. The ethical questions raised by the unauthorized use of someone's cells are important to ask and ponder. But most fascinating is the story of the Lacks family. Skloot's exhaustive research spanned a decade and she tells a story that is honest, heart wrenching and provocative.

This is one stellar piece of nonfiction that has a bit of everything in it for everybody. Beautifully written and structured because it is clear that while there's SOoo much information here, it is arranged in such a way that you don't get lost. Sure the author is a science writer, but she's also a creative nonfiction writer so the book doesn't read like a nonfiction textbook, and has the plot structure of fiction. Some chapters tell the story of Henrietta Lacks and her family, others take you on the research journey with Rebecca Skloot. The interactions she has with the family makes for light, sometimes humorous reading. In fact, the chronology is done in a way to make the book more interesting. The book is as much about family, as it is about science, history, racial tensions, and of one extraordinary black woman who has done more for medical research and advancements, than anything or anyone the industry has seen. It will have you crying, laughing, yelling at people...you name it. Born in 1920, Henrietta Lacks was thirty years old when she went to see a doctor for "spotting" and pain, and started getting treatments for cervical cancer (mind you, in the "colored" wards of John Hopkins. This was during the Jim Crow era). The researcher/doctor who treated her, collected samples of her cells (without her knowledge) while he placed radium inside of her. She soon deteriorated and each time she went in for treatment, her cells were taken and stored. Yet she knew nothing of the cells growing in a lab, or the fact that she was now infertile because of her cancer treatment. When she died, her husband signed paperwork to have an autopsy performed, because he was under the impression that doctors would find out if his children were predisposed to whatever his wife had, not knowing that his signature allowed his wife's body to be cut open to help with more research.This is the breadth of the story I think. A story about an African-American woman whose life and death seemed to be an irony--she wasn't allowed to mention her white, slave-owning family, yet she was buried next to them. She wasn't allowed to use the "white-only" medical facilities, yet her cells were mixed with white cells. In science cell culture, there were no other cells with the ability to multiply and stay immortal like hers. So every major medical breakthrough, like polio vaccine for example, came from the usage of her cells. The main thrust is, she didn't know. Her family didn't know, and they didn't find out until twenty years later because the name Henrietta Lacks was hidden by the doctors who used her cells as research. Scientists made millions from her body and her family had tons of health issues, with no help from their mother's cells and no health insurance. "A search of U.S. Patent and Trademark Office database turns up more than seventeen thousand patents involving HeLa Cells," Skloot wrote. But Henrietta's son Lawrence wanted to know, "She's the most important woman in the world and her family living in poverty. If our mother is so important to science, why can't we get health insurance?"There they were, at a time when the country was learning about the "Tuskegee Syphilis Study" (where African-American men with syphilis were recruited for research, then made to die slow, painful deaths even after their researchers realized that penicillin would cure them), and cells from a black woman was being used to save millions of Americans, mostly white.In this book, Skloot brings the woman behind the cells to life, talks about her life, her troubled marriage, her children. She develops a relationship with Deborah, Henrietta's daughter who suffered the most from all of it. She talks to scientists and researchers. She brings in history. She talks about race tensions and shows how when slavery was abolished, African-Americans became slaves to another master: medicine. I'll admit, at times it was an emotional roller coaster for me, but one quote from Deborah stood out for me and should for you:"Like I'm always telling my brothers, if you gonna go into history, you can't do it with a hate attitude. You got to remember, times was different."So anybody should be able to read this book because the way in which it is written, is not to point fingers (not even at the medical industry because the author manages to explain those times as well) but to glean the truth. To finally give credit where credit is due, and to educate. To honor a woman, a mother, a wife, whose body makes it possible for us to get some of the modern medical treatments that we get today. This is one book I will remember, that's for sure!

In 1951, Henrietta Lacks passed away due to complications arising from cervical cancer. Following her death, cancerous cells were harvested from her body and used in ongoing experiments regarding the growth of cells outside the human body. Previous to Henrietta, scientists could only make it a few days before the cells would ultimately die, forcing them to start all over. Henrietta’s cells were different, they grew at an astounding rate and researchers were able to keep them alive. Since the discovery, they've been used in countless experiments and led to numerous scientific breakthroughs - most notably the polio vaccine.Today, Henrietta’s cells usually go for a few hundred dollars a vial but her descendants live in poverty. While many of her children believe they should be compensated for the sale of HeLa cells, court cases involving similar claims have always found in favor of research companies rather than individuals - the argument being that once a procedure is performed and tissue is removed from a body, it is no longer of use to the individual and the hospital can do with it as it pleases, be it incineration or study. On one hand, it makes sense given that it was highly doubtful Henrietta’s husband could have opened a cellular research facility, however, the problem lies within the fact that researchers did not tell Henrietta’s family about the importance of HeLa cells and lied to her children when additional bloodwork was requested for further study.The story of the Lacks family is a heartbreaking one. Henrietta had a terrible upbringing and following her death, things became that much worse for her children. While the book mainly concentrates on the HeLa cells, there’s a shocking piece on her daughter Elsie, who had been diagnosed with “idiocy” and institutionalized at Crownsville Hospital Centre (a.k.a. The Hospital for the Negro Insane) following her mother’s death. The conditions at the time of Elsie’s arrival were deplorable. They had a total of eight attendants (four in the day, four in the evening) for five hundred and sixty patients. One ward in particular had seventy eight patients with only twenty eight beds. There were also only three toilets to share amongst them all. You can imagine how much this upset the family when they found out decades later.While The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks can be deeply upsetting, it is without a doubt an important book. Author Rebecca Skloot spent years interviewing the Lacks family (which at times was certainly no easy task) and researching Henrietta’s life and death, all information that had been buried over time. The story flows well and her afterword provides greater insight into the legal ramifications of future soft tissue research. Henrietta’s youngest daughter Deborah always wanted the world to know about the person behind the HeLa cells, the real human being who provided the ammunition for several medical discoveries. Thanks to Rebecca’s tireless work, Henrietta Lacks' incredible true story is out there for the world to see.Also posted @ Every Read Thing.

4.5 starsThere's something here for everyone. Some people comment on the human interest aspect of the story with regard to the Lacks family. Other people mention the cell science. For me, the most interesting thing was the history of informed consent, or the "Lacks" thereof. (Go ahead and laugh now at my clever wordplay. You know you want to.)It's hard to believe the bizarre ways people's bodies were used for medical research, with or without their consent. Even when they did give consent, they did so without being told exactly what would be done to their bodies. Too often the people used for the studies were the poor, the uneducated, and prison inmates. Back in the forties and fifties, "Many scientists believed that since patients were treated for free in the public wards, it was fair to use them as research subjects as a form of payment." YIKES! That's not just unethical, it's abominable.Rebecca Skloot's dedication to the research and writing of this story is remarkable. She spent pretty much the entire decade of her twenties in pursuit of the truth about Henrietta Lacks and her "immortal" cells. My only reason for not awarding the full five stars is that I thought the book could have used one more ruthless edit before final printing.

This book has been an incredible read! Clearly, a result of hard work and intense research and, above all the fact that the author has taken student loans and used her credit cards for the research work and had no other backing or support. The story of Henrietta Lacks is a required read for all, specifically for those interested in life and science.
This book broke my heart and made me think. It's a book that will be with you for years. The Lacks family are an amazing group of people, portrayed as human.

An unforgettable book written by Rebecca Skloot telling the saga of Henrietta Lacks' family in order to really know and understand what happened to her when a doctor from John Hopkins Hospital took a sample of her cells (HeLa cells, from her full name), without her consent and her knowledge, in order to provide culture of cells which have been used for decades for research of several diseases, cancer among them. Even nowadays, the medical ethics is questionable is some cases, even with the advent of the Declaration of Helsinki which is not a legally binding instrument in international law.

I’m going to be the party pooper here. I know everyone is suppose to love this book. I know that the issues the book deals with are very important and books like this should be written.	But this book didn’t do it for me. I found it dull, I found it facile, and the only interesting part was looking at race in Clover which sadly was too short. “Henrietta’s (cells) were different: they reproduced an entire generation every twenty-four hours, and they never stopped. They became the first immortal human cells ever grown in a laboratory.”  Argh, I feel embarrassed admitting this, but before reading this book, I had no idea what the HeLa cells were. I never studied science in-depth, which is now one of my biggest regrets. However, I guess in some ways I was lucky: I got to know who Henrietta Lacks was before meeting her famous cells. In this well-researched biography, Rebecca Skloot tells the story of Henrietta Lacks, a poor Black woman who was only 31 when she died from cervical cancer. While she was getting treatments at John Hopkins Hospital, Dr. George Guy took cells from Lack’s tumor without her consent. After examining her cells, Guy felt amazed. He realized her cells were unlike any he had seen - Henrietta’s cells refused to die.HeLa would become the first immortal cell line grown in a lab. For scientists, this discovery was monumental. It would allow them to conduct experiments they never could before. Henrietta’s cells would later help create in vitro fertilization, polio vaccines, and cancer treatments. Although HeLa cells have affected each of us in different ways, before this book’s publication, most of us had little to no idea who Henrietta Lacks was.Here is what I found riveting: Henrietta never graduated from high school, yet she became one of the most important people in science. Sure, science has its own explanation for how this happened, but her family believed God chose Henrietta. God wanted her to come back to Earth in the form of her cells to help others. Since the Lacks had a weak science background, faith was their way of understanding what happened to Henrietta, and making sense of the non-sensical. Though most of the Lacks were happy Henrietta’s cells were advancing science, some of them were mad. The Lacks had no science education, and scientists never bothered to explain to them what happened to Henrietta in a simple way. Researchers exploited their ignorance and the Lacks were never able to give informed consent. Their frustrations are understandable. I felt like giving each of them a hug when I read these passages. If I were them, I would be upset too. While HeLa cells were becoming a multi-million dollar industry, the Lacks were living in poverty, barely able to afford health insurance:   “...the last thing he remembered before falling into unconsciousness under anesthesia was a doctor standing over him saying his mother's cells were one of the most important things that had ever happened to medicine. Sonny woke up more than $125,000 in debt because he didn't have health insurance to cover the surgery.”  I also admire Skloot's grit because this was a massive project to undertake. I can understand why this book took her a decade to write. I think she wanted to do Henrietta's story justice, and she did. Skloot made sure the world knew about the Lacks and what they did for science. Furthermore, I liked that Skloot’s discussed the social determinants of health. Her clear prose helped me better understand patient rights, inequalities in medicine, informed consent, and tissue ownership laws. Overall, “The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks" was a magnificent treat. I am positive other readers will find this book as informative and awe-inspiring as I did.

Skloot delivers a mix of science history and human interest in her journalistic style. She discusses medical ethics particularly the issue of informed consent as she tells the story of Henrietta Lacks. Henrietta was a poor black woman who joined the great migration of the 1940’s moving from rural southern Virginia to Baltimore, Maryland. She was treated for cervical cancer at Johns Hopkins, the only nearby hospital that would admit blacks in 1951. After suffering through the then standard radium therapy, she died that same year. Samples of her tumor were removed and became the first successful human cell culture to sustain itself. Known as HeLa her cells live on today in labs around the world the subject of endless experimentation. Most of the book is spent on Henrietta’s life, her daughter Deborah, their families and extended relations as well as the author’s work with the family to research the book. We follow Henrietta from her childhood in the 1920’s growing up in former slave quarters on the wrong side of the tracks in the small tobacco country town of Clover, Virginia. Skloot gives a somewhat romanticized version of what must have been a harsh life of poverty and discrimination. Similarly Skloot tries to bring out the positives while dutifully reporting the difficult lives of Henrietta’s descendants who suffer from chronic mental and physical illnesses, limited education and continued discrimination in the Baltimore area. Particularly interesting to me was the communication gap between the scientists and Henrietta’s working class African American family. A big part of the problem was the history of exploitation of African Americans by white doctors and their medical institutions. This history had been internalized into a pervasive distrust of doctors and hospitals by Henrietta’s family. Henrietta’s and her family’s fear is understandable and it struck me as part of a broader issue. With unarmed black men dying regularly at the hands of the police, we see similar fears by African Americans today. Skloot points out that scientific progress was made from practices that now would be clearly unethical. Henrietta’s cells sped up the development of the Polio vaccine in the early 1950’s saving many from this devastating disease. Concepts such as informed consent did not exist in 1951. Even today the issue is very murky which the author addresses in her afterword. At the end of the book Skloot returns to Clover to find it gone. All the ramshackle old buildings torn down, just empty fields remaining. Most of those who knew Henrietta had now passed on too. Only her cells remain, thriving in labs everywhere and generating the ground breaking medical discoveries of a new era.

In the same way we sometimes debate whether the story should be seen as an entirely seperate entity to the writer, so too do scientists perceive a sample of cell tissue as seperate to the human body it was extracted from. Except that it is not possible to extract a story from a writer's imagination without their consent. Henrietta Lacks was a young mother in her early thirties when she was diagnosed with an aggressive form of cancer that would quickly take her life. She was fortunate to live close to the John Hopkins hospital, set up to ensure equal access to medical care for all' no matter their race, status, income or any other characteristic that might have otherwise given cause to discriminate.Before undergoing treatment, one of the Doctors took a tissue sample of her healthy cells and the cancerous cells, as he had been doing to most patients, in an effort to try and find cells that would continue to replicate without dying - the elusive "immortal" cell. It had never been done successfully with human cells before.He succeeded and the cells became known the world over as he gave them away freely, known as HeLa cells, the immortal human cells that never died and could be used over and over again to test for cures to disease and to observe how cells react to numerous variables, furthering science in ways unimaginable previously. Few paused to ask who the woman behind these cells was, what was her story, how did her family feel about this multi million dollar research industry that was making great strides in science yes, and also making entrepreneurial types wealthy in the process.Rebecca Skloot made Henrietta the subject of her research for 10 years in the creation of this thorough, respectful account of the life of Henrietta Lacks and her journey to uncover the events of the time within the context of what was the norm in her day. In much of it she is accompanied by Henriettas daughter Deborah, a passionate woman who was unable to find peace in her own life, until she had helped bring her mother's story to light.A brilliant and informative story and piece of scientific medical history that reads like a novel and brings our awareness to the many who unknowingly make sacrifices for the better of others and that always present aspect of those hovering in the wings, recognising an opportunity to profit.

There is no getting around the fact that this is an incredibly necessary and important American story. The votes have been in for years: author Rebecca Skloot’s book racked up 19 significant awards and citations in 2010 when it was first published. The 2011 trade paperback edition I read boasts five pages of exuberant blurbs before you even get to the title page. I wanted to be a curmudgeon about it, but the story is so serious that I had to relinquish my pissy attitude. It is just that type of story: a sensational true crime story with ramifications in the fields of health and science; race and sociology; ethics, history, and journalism. Suspenseful, cinematic, and factual, Ms. Skloot manages to pack it all inside of 310 pages, with 71 pages remaining for appendices, acknowledgements, notes, and discussion group questions! She writes knowledgeably, intelligently, compassionately, and skillfully. This book is all that! The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks is the story of Henrietta Lacks and her family. It is about the miraculous and immortal cells---taken from her cervix without her permission in 1951 and how they have been serving medical research ever since. It is a story about her daughter, Deborah, and a science journalist (Rebecca Skloot) dedicating years of her life to questioning, investigating, researching, and writing. It is about injustice and justice; human liberties, and privileging science over human life and the right to make informed decisions. This book chillingly illustrates the complex path of ethics and medical research in the United States from the 1950s to the present. It made me mad, but it also educated me in a profound way.

An incredible book that affected me long after I read the last page. In fact this is the first book to keep me so intellectually and emotionally engaged in a very long time. I struggle to find the words to express what it meant to read about the plight of this woman and the medical knowledge gained from her cells. To read this book is to begin to understand the impact of these cells on modern medicine. Then the book takes you further to read about what has happened to her family during these medical breakthroughs, the impact of what happened and its influences on the laws and the practice of medicine. Just an amazing book with so many elements intertwined and presented with such empathy and beauty. As a brief aside, shortly after I finished the book I had a minor medical procedure performed. Before they would begin, the patient must sign a medical release form and on the form was a statement asking the patient to relinquish all rights of ownership to any tissue samples removed. After reading this book I understand the implications (signed it, but was much more aware of the rationale behind it). This was a life affecting book for me. I didn't close the book thinking that I knew the answers to the ethical questions it raised. What I did feel was that it just seemed some how unjust that her family fared so poorly when her cells were so vital to so many of the scientific advancements made after her death. It presented legal and ethical quandaries that some of the finest legal minds still haven't wrapped their minds around. Engaging and enlightening book? And how!! Highly recommended!!!

4.5 stars. As someone who is strongly considering donating my body to science when I die, this was a probative read to think about the changing ethics of medicine, and a reminder that so much scientific development has been done on unwilling, non-consenting, and uninformed individuals. Top among these unwitting contributors, must rank Henrietta Lacks, whose indomitable cancer cells have led to inestimable developments. I listened to this book on audio and for the first time I felt like I read a non fiction book that didn't feel like homework. But I'm a lot smarter for it and feel so strongly outraged by the treatment of Henrietta and no doubt millions of others, in the name of science and 'advancement'.
