“Everybody in the world got her cells, only thing we got of our mother is just them medical records and her Bible.”
In 1951 doctors at Johns Hopkins in Baltimore diagnosed an unusually extreme case of cervical cancer. The breakneck growth rate and resistance to common remedies were unlike anything previously seen. Without informed consent, the doctor scraped a clump of cells from the cancerous tumor during one of the 30 year-old woman’s visits and deposited them with a nearby cell culture lab operated by George Gey. There, in the air-controlled space of Gey’s facility, something happened that researchers had long suspected out of reach. Where countless other cells before them had died, hers survived, and multiplied indefinitely. The immortality of this one cell line would prove instrumental in treating a number of the world’s most heavy-hitting diseases and set the stage for an all new era in cell research, medical diagnosis, drug development and bioethics. But this is a story not just about bundles of cells, but about the humanity behind them, and in particular the family to which they will forever be tied.That woman was Henrietta Lacks. Henrietta passed away just nine months after diagnosis, but it would be more than two decades before her family received word of the namesake cell line which survived her—HeLa. Its value as a scientific and commercial commodity was paramount, getting bogged down in the thicket of rights and privacy less so. Once researchers discovered that Henrietta’s cells did not die but instead bred a new generation every twenty-four hours, HeLa quickly became the tireless workhorse of the culture community. Vials were trucked to research facilities around the world, where they were regularly exposed to a pavilion of infectious diseases, merged with non-human DNA, and even shot into space in an effort to study the influence of zero gravity.Over time, details about the parent of the eponymous cells funneled out of view. Henrietta’s own kin were oblivious to the fact that her cells lived, were being studied and tested in dozens of countries, and were being exchanged at great profit. Once the unwitting donor’s official name was released, journalists descended in full fervor, leading to a lifetime of turmoil and unrest for the Lacks household. Set against the rich legacy of the family’s cells, their life of poverty and unpaid medical bills seemed untoward by comparison, and this sense of injustice only mounted as more details filtered in from the press.Rebecca Skloot’s segue into this lush narrative was by and large a product of serendipitous circumstance, having first heard of HeLa in an intro to biology course at her local community college. After learning that these cells had lived outside their host's body for the better part of a century, and about the remarkable advances they have gifted to science, Skloot shot up her hand and innocently asked, "Who was she?" The professor's reply proved unsatisfying: "An African American woman." The seed of curiosity had been planted. By the time Skloot graduated she'd decided to write a book to recover the disremembered woman whose cells had won so many victories for science and society.Who Was Henrietta Lacks?For more than a decade, Skloot layered herself into the Lacks’ story, befriending and forming deep bonds with Henrietta’s children and cousinry. She forges an especially strong connection with Deborah Lacks, Henrietta’s youngest daughter, who was unfortunately too young to remember much about her mother. With a mix of patience and persistence the two work together to dig up Henrietta’s heritage and bring to light her hitherto uncelebrated legacy. It is Skloot’s at times unstable relationship and camaraderie with Deborah that gives the narrative its steam, as the two probe ever deeper into the mystery surrounding her mother.Tracing the family’s roots places Henrietta’s childhood at the tail end of the Jim Crow era, a time when segregation meant a great deal more than which bathroom and water fountain one was required to use. Rampant legal disadvantages in the South bred systemic, institutionalized maladjustment for blacks, and this included limited access to medical care. Having spent her youth on a slave plantation in Clover, Virginia, Henrietta joined in the Great Migration at the ripened age of twenty-one, exchanging her familiarity with tobacco fields for a new life in Baltimore. Nine years later, she would be diagnosed with the malignancy that led to her iconic cell line. And it would be another fifty years before Deborah, with the help of Skloot, laid eyes on her mother’s original medical records.Johns Hopkins Hospital was founded for the express purpose of treating Baltimore's poor and, unlike today, informed consent upon providing blood or tissue samples was neither required by law nor common practice (the term did not even appear in a court document until 1957). Like everyone at the time, Henrietta hadn't a clue about what would become of her excised genetic material and the boons it would lavish upon the scientific community. This became a flashpoint issue in the years that followed as the occasional patient attempted to turn a gray area into a lucrative venture. While we learned more about DNA and transmissible disease, Henrietta's resilient cells inaugurated an international conversation on the commercialization of biological materials and where exactly the donors fit within that ecosystem. In many ways, the conversation is ongoing. (Skloot includes a superb summary in the afterword which draws together the various threads of this nuanced debate.) The HeLa LegacyTo properly gauge the vastitude of the legacy tied up in Henrietta’s cells, it’s important to understand 20th century cell culture. Until Henrietta came along, cell immortality was a pipe dream. While standard, non-cancerous cells had been grown in vitro since 1907, none of them survived long enough to endure important testing, petering out after 50 divisions, on average. Even cancer cells, like those common to cervical cancers, died shortly after relocation to the culture environment. This meant not only was there a brief window for experimentation but that a continuous supply of fresh cells was needed to sustain research. Many in the field yearned for a better way.HeLa keynoted a paradigm shift. They were robust enough to survive in the bricolage of materials used in Dr. Gey’s culture medium, and they were susceptible to the same range of infectious diseases as were normal cells. This allowed researchers to inject the lively DNA with diseases as well as cures. Not merely a boon to science, this revolutionized the field, so much so that one of the researchers Skloot interviews in the book, when asked what would happen if HeLa was pulled from research use, replied, “Restricting HeLa cell use would be disastrous. The impact that would have on science is inconceivable.” (p. 328)Thanks to Dr. Gey’s partnering efforts with labs around the globe, the benefits of HeLa manifested seemingly overnight. In just one year after HeLa’s genesis, Jonas Salk and his team were able to derive a vaccine for polio by infecting HeLa cells, followed shortly by drug treatments for HPV, herpes, leukemia, influenza, hemophilia and Parkinson’s disease. In 1953 HeLa became the first cells to be cloned successfully. In total, some 60,000 papers have been published on HeLa, and cell culturists still use her cancer cells as a model for human biology.What was it exactly that gave HeLa cells their added dose of moxie? Even today, we can only speculate. We now know that Henrietta was infected with both HPV and syphilis, so one theory is that this virulent combination may have helped suppress PCD. A rival theory suggests she had highly atypical genes to begin with, perhaps a rare mutation, that enabled the cancer to spiral in unspecified directions. We still are uncertain. HeLa has also been the source of much frustration over the years from regularly contaminating other cell lines, often halting research until the botch-up is sorted.Closing ThoughtsRebecca Skloot’s ten-year effort is a literary and cultural marvel balanced between unsheathing the posthumous success and humanity behind one of the richest narratives in science and laying bare the bioethical implications to which it is attached. It succeeds on both fronts. Skloot is at her most animating when channeling the lens of Deborah Lacks as they band together to reach some much-needed closure to the saga thrust upon the Lacks family. With her first book, Skloot has demonstrated in equal measure her facility for conveying scientific nuance while weaving meaning and poetic force into a cohesive whole. Yes, this is first and foremost a work of nonfiction, but its pages are emblazoned with enough touches of novel-like charisma to beckon both crowds. The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks is a timeless story delivered by a gifted writer and the definitive presentation of the legacy Henrietta never lived to see. Highly recommended.Skloot also founded The Henrietta Lacks Foundation - click here for more - to provide support for the Lacks as well as assistance to African Americans pursuing education in science and medicine. A portion of her book’s proceeds are donated to the Foundation.Note: This review is republished from my official website. Click through for additional footnotes and imagery.

A really powerful read about HeLa cells, taken without consent from a woman named Henrietta Lacks. Her cells contributed to many of modern medicines discoveries, including the polio vaccine and gene mapping, and yet her family is still so poor they cannot afford health care hacing seen none of the money generated by these cells.This book explores the debate about what makes up a person's body. Is a shed skin cell the property of the person whose DNA is within the cell, or have they given up their ownership? And what exactly constitutes informed consent?I thought it was a fascinating read, and while it appealed to my Science background by explaining the advances made, and the complications that arose, it also brought to light the bittersweet story of the family that thought they had lost their mother, and never knew that a little piece of her still existed until years after her death.A powerful read I'd recommend to everyone.

In The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks (ILHL), Skloot blends the Lacks' family history with that of medical sciences and all against a backdrop of systemic racism. For decades, her cell line, named HeLa, has far eclipsed the woman of their origin. Henrietta Lacks was born in 1920 as the ninth child of Eliza and Johnny Pleasant in Roanoke, Virginia. When Eliza died after birthing her tenth child in 1924, the family was divided amongst the larger network of relatives who pitched in to raise the children. Henrietta and David Lacks, her first cousin and future spouse, were raised together by their grandfather Tommy in a former slaves quarter cabin in Lacks Town (Clover), Virginia. Lacks Town had been the inheritance carved out of Henrietta's white great grandfather Albert Lacks' tobacco plantation in the late 1800s.From Skloot's interviews with relatives, Henrietta was a generously hospitable, hard working, and loving mother whose premature death led to enormous consequences for her children. Henrietta suspected a health problem a year before her fifth and last child was born. She went to Johns Hopkins, a renowned medical institution and a charity hospital, in Baltimore and received a diagnosis of cervical cancer in January 1951. (view spoiler)[Since cervical cancer is caused by a sexually transmitted virus, it seems likely that she had contracted the virus from her husband, who had not been monogamous. (hide spoiler)]During her first treatment for cancer, malignant cells were removed - without Henrietta's knowledge - and cultivated in a lab environment by Johns Hopkins researchers attempting to uncover cancer's secrets. Although the brachytherapy with radium was initially deemed a success, Henrietta's brown skin turned black as the cancer aggressively metastasized. After several weeks of great pain, Henrietta died in October 1951.ILHL raises questions about the extent to which we own our bodies, informed consent, and ethics surrounding the research of anything human. The HeLa line was a rare scientific success as those malignant cells thrived in lab conditions and eventually became crucial to thousands of research projects. Skloot reported that in 2009, an average human body was worth anywhere from $10,000 to $150,000. In the case of John Moore who had leukemia, his cell line was valued in millions of dollars. To prevent human trafficking, it is illegal to sell human organs and tissues, but they can be donated while processing fees are assessed.As a charity hospital in the 1950s, segregated patient wards in Johns Hopkins were filled with African Americans whose tissue samples were regarded by researchers as "payment." One cannot "donate" what one doesn't know. The Lacks family discovered HeLa's existence 22 years after Henrietta died. They've struggled to pay their medical costs while biotechnology companies have reaped profits from cultivating and selling HeLa cells. In 1999, the Rand Corporation estimated that 307 million tissue samples from  178 million  people (almost 60 percent of the population) were stored in the US for research purposes. Although the US is nowhere close to definitively addressing the questions raised by ILHL , a little progress has been made. In 1974, the Federal Policy for Protection of Human Subjects (the "Common Rule") required informed consent for federally funded research. The Common Rule was passed in response to egregious and inhumane experiments such as the Tuskegee Syphilis project and another scientist who wanted to know whether injecting people with HeLa would give them cancer. Note that this rule exempts privately funded research. In 1996, the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA) made it illegal for health practitioners and insurers to make one's medical information public without their consent. This was after researchers had published medical information about the Lacks family. It should be evident that human tissues have long been monetized. One method of creating monopoly - like control has been to obtain a patent. As of 2005, the US has issued patents for about 20 percent of all known human genes. Myriad Genetics patented two genes - BRCA1 and BRCA2 - indicative of breast and ovarian cancer. In 2009 the American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU), on behalf of scientists, sued Myriad Genetics. In 2013, the US Supreme Court gave the victory to the ACLU and invalidated the patents, thus lowering future research costs and obliquely taking a step toward defining ownership of the human body.

Henrietta Lacks was a mother to four children and about to become one for the fifth time when she started to feel sick. After the birth of her son, she only grew sicker. At John Hopkins, she was diagnosed with cervical cancer and underwent treatment. Unfortunately, the cancer spread quickly and Henrietta died. Before her death, a sample of her cancerous tissue was taken and cultivated in the lab. Her cells grew at an unprecedated rate and became extremely valuable to the scientific realm. Called HeLa, Henrietta's cells were the first to reach "immortality". Her family did not know this information for several years. This is the story of the woman behind the cells.I began reading more non-fiction books last year and have since come across some amazing works. 'The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks' will join those ranks. Hands down, this is one of the best non-fiction books written. Broad-in-scope, thought-provocking, awe-inspiring and jaw-dropping, this book is the perfect marriage between science and human interest. Greatly researched and with much heart, the prose is magnificent. Henrietta Lacks was a poor tobacco farmer, descended from slaves. When she was diagnosed with cervical cancer, she did not particularly stand out but when her cancerous tissue was cultivated in the Hopkins lab, that was a different story. Until HeLa, scientists had not been able to produce a cell line that perdured. With HeLa cells, however, they hit the jackpot. Used in everything from the development of vaccines to genetic research and even to test out the effects of a nuclear bomb, the impact of these cells is immesurable. Just one problem, Henrietta did not give consent to give her cells and her family did not learn of just how important Henrietta was until many years after her death. About 50 miillion metric tons of HeLa cells have been produced to date, more than enough cells to populate a village full of Henriettas. While Henritta never travelled far form her home, her cells have been all over the world and even into outer space. They have been infected with several illnesses and combined with other cells. Odds are eah of us has, in some way, come in contact with HeLa.The way in which Skloot balances the science aspect with the human asprct of the book is done with finnesse. The HeLa cells are something impressive but more so is the woman behind them. Henrietta was strong, confident and resourceful. By all accounts, she faced her cancer diagnosis with sheer bravery and never stopped thinking about her family, even when she knew she would not survive. Its truly sad that for that Henriettas's cells did for the world, her heirs do not even know where the exact location of her grave is. What stood out for me most was the relationship that developed between Sloot and Deborah (Henrietta's daughter). Until Skloot, most were merely interested in the cells with Henrietta as an afterthought. I love that Skloot focused on Henrietta. Its time she gets the recognition that is way overdue.This work raises many questions. With the "Tissue Issue", consent and scientific progress are at a standstill. Henrietta's cells were taken without her knowledge or that of her family. The exact amount of money made off the HeLa cells is not known but its exorbitant. Her family never saw a cent and sadly struggle to pay their health insurance. Biological ownership is a tricky subject matter. The John Moore case was one of the cases that put it on the map and it has been a hot botton issue since. While there are some basic rules to follow, the gist is that once any tissue is "abandoned" at a hospital, it ceases to be property of the patient. Blood tests, biopsies and tissue taken from surgeries are property of the hospital and they have no obligation to let their patients know if and for what their tissues can be used. The scientific communty argues that to seek consent would lead to a decreased access to materials or have people seek financial gain. Personally, I find this troubling. The moral and ethical concerns are overwhelming and getting to an agreement between both parties is a battle. Scientific progress is important but at what cost? This is a book that will stay with me for a while. Its up there with 'The Radium Girls' (another great non-fiction work). Highly recommended!

2.5 stars. I found the 1st 1/2 of this book fascinating and eagerly awaited to hear more of Henrietta's story. Henrietta was someone you couldn't help but root for and you were amazed to hear of her strength and perpetual optimism. The 2nd 1/2 of this book was tedious and annoying. The book started to drag and focus too much on the researcher's hardships, but mostly, I found Henrietta's family to be utterly unlikable. I kept thinking of that saying, "I can explain it to you, but I can't understand it for you". I felt much of the Lacks family, particularly Deborah and Joe (who changed his name to the long Z name), enjoyed being miserable. Despite being corrected again and again on their misbeliefs, they would resort right back to harboring on their anger/hatred/anxiousness over falsities. I felt their actions reflected a disregard for much of the advancements that came about from their mother's indirect contribution to medicine, but focused instead on a victim mentality and desire for monetary contribution - monetary contribution for something they had absolutely nothing to do with and had not worked for one iota.  As for the ethics surrounding Henrietta's cells being taken, be it right or wrong, she was not treated any differently than rich white patients were at that time when it came to taking cells/tissue without informed consent. In that sense, I don't think she was personally wronged in an intentional manner, though I think it's crazy what could be done without informed consent at that time. If you want to talk about who was wronged in an intentional manner, we'll talk about Elsie. Furthermore, I'm not completely convinced that some things were not explained to Henrietta regarding sampling cells. It was stated by Henrietta and the Lacks family time and again that they often came away with a poor understanding after speaking with MDs, yet they did not ask further questions or state their lack of understanding. Therefore, anytime it was exclaimed they were told "nothing", I had doubts. Henrietta's cells as they were taken, were of very little worth. It was the ingenuity of the people that used them that gave them their worth. Should Henrietta have received a modest compensation? Perhaps, it's muddled for me. Organ donors do not receive compensation (or their families). The reward is knowing you have saved other's lives. Should her children be entitled to compensation decades later for advancements that continue to be made 50 years after the cells were taken - cells that were not even from their own body? Definitely not. Is her family entitled to give permission for what can and cannot be done to Henrietta's cells? Absolutely not. Informed consent (which was not legally required at that time) is between the patient and the MD - what other family members wish is insignificant. The most interesting part of this story for me was easily Henrietta's story. Her childhood, the abuse of the time to the poor and minorities, the overt racist culture, and her strong optimistic nature that she maintained despite the world burning around her. The part that made the story a chore to finish was the ignorance that the family clung to despite being informed of truths, and the smallness with which they appreciated the lives that have been saved due to the awful cancer their mother acquired compared to the greatness with which they felt they deserved money as a result of research and ingenuity that they had never participated in, let alone understood. Azle - 7/16

This remarkable story about how people live on sometimes in the material way just as much as in memory, about science, ethics, the search for a cure to a potentially deadly disease, well, it's unforgettable and unlike any other book because it wasn't just her cells that kept Henrietta alive after her death - it was her family, whose lives were transformed upon hearing of her story and the research done on cells taken without her consent.

I absolutely loved this book! The intense ethical, moral, legal, and scientific dilemma that arise throughout the book make this book a MUST read! It is very well written and has given me so many things to think about. I am so glad my book club is reading this book for our first ever meeting. I am thrilled to be able to discuss the book in detail! I highly recommend this book to everyone.

20th century medicine is another area of institutional racism that the story of Henrietta Lacks illustrates in very fine detail. Those who claim there is nothing different in the treatment of whites and blacks in health care and medicine need to read this story. When will the sorrow end?

I’m not in a scientific field & I don’t remember studying anything about HeLa cells in school but when this book came across my radar (the mother I work for purchased it) I had to read it. I’m pretty ignorant to the inner workings of the medical research world but the ethics of using cells seems pretty clear. I’m thrilled HeLa cells have lead to epic medical breakthroughs and continue to help find cures for cancer, etc. but what the Lacks family has gone through when their mother’s cells are involved is heartbreaking. Currently, HeLa cells are being used to try and find a cure and vaccine for Covid-19. The widespread medical advances that were/are possible thanks to Henrietta Lacks and her immortal cells are staggering and a blessing. So reading about her family, too poor to afford health care and medicine their mother’s cells likely helped develop is just shitty. Still, I’m so happy I read this book and educated myself. TW: (severe) child abuse, graphic medical situations, cancer, molestation, pedophilia, incest, mistreatment if mentally handicapped in hospital settings in 50s, mistreatment, abuse, and murder of black people at the hands of the medical field, murder, drug use, cheating, domestic abuse... this isn’t an easy read, friends.

Skloot, Rebecca - The Immortal Life of Henrietta LacksThis has been on my TBR list for most of the year. I knew I wanted to read it as soon as I heard it involved The HeLa Cells. Somewhere in the back of my mind I knew I had heard about these famous cells taken from an African American woman diagnosed with cervical cancer in the 50’s. The cells were taken without her knowledge and without the knowledge of her family. The cells lived, she did not. Meet Henrietta Lacks.Like the author, Rebecca Skloot, I was curious to know more about Henrietta, to learn more about the details of the cell experimentations, what they have done for science and why they are important to our lives. Skloot is a science journalist and has the credentials to dig into the story and inform. I give her a great deal of credit for the ten years she took to research the book and for having the perseverance to continue to contact Henrietta’s relatives who were reluctant to talk to a reporter. Building trust with the family was not an easy task, but eventually Skloot was able to ensure them that her intentions were good. Though the story could have been told from interviews with doctors and possibly from records at Johns Hopkins, what really brings Henrietta alive in my mind is the personal stories of her kin, particularly her daughter, Deborah. I liked the format Skloot used to write the book. You can hear what she says about this in the FAQ portion of her website.Critics of the book complain that Skloot has made this a story of race. Personally, I don’t see how you can begin to know Henrietta and her family without talking about race. But, yes, it is more than that. It’s about informed consent, pharmaceutical companies making mega dollars, treatment of patients, and ethics. It is also the story of the quest of a daughter to better know her mother, who died when she was young. It is a story of this daughter’s love for the woman she comes to know. I am pleased that Rebecca Skloot has set up Henrietta Lacks Foundation, which this year granted five of the Lacks descendents for their education. There is much to think about after reading this book. I still have questions. Some of the science goes over my head, but Skloot did a good job keeping this in layman’s terms. Today, due to privacy laws we would not know the name of the woman that the cells were harvested from. I’m in agreement with this but am still glad that in this case, Henrietta Lacks was identified and that through the efforts of Rebecca Skloot that I have a better picture of who Henrietta was. She never knew her contribution to medicine, but it seems to be significant.

I'm having a hard time accepting the fundamental premise of this book; that because Henrietta Lacks's cancer cells continue to grow and have since the 50s, she herself is somehow still alive. Because she's not. And these are cancer cells anyway - of her body, but not of her personally. If you scraped a cancer cell out of me, it wouldn't take care of my kid or go to work for me, so why would you say that I was still alive? I think a lot of Deborah Lacks's heartache might've been averted if this myth of Henrietta's aliveness hadn't been perpetuated. Without being told that her mother was still "alive", she'd have no need to stress out to the point of almost stroking out about her mother still being able to feel the pain of an atomic bomb blast, the pain of cancer treatment drugs, AIDS drugs, etc. I'm in no way denying the achievement of HeLa cells or what they've done to further scientific achievement, I just can't buy that their existence means that Henrietta Lacks is still alive.

Wow. I was enthralled during the first half of the book but it started to drag at the end. Definetly lost its magic of storytelling at the end and almost sounded just like retyped journal notes. BUT this tells an important story that should be required for all medical scientists. It humanizes their work and ties this to real people.
A well researched and exquisitely told story. I listened to the audio which was highly entertaining. Absolutely fascinating! It's hard to believe this happened in the 1950's!!

From my blog: https://bookgirl1987thoughts.wordpres...I'm sure many of you have already read this book, as it was published in early 2010 and made headlines as a bestselling piece of medical/science nonfiction. Rebecca Skloot is an award-winning science writer who became interested in the story of Henrietta Lacks (known as HeLa in the medical/scientific community) when she took a biology course at sixteen that changed her outlook on the world of science forever. Her instructor wrote the name HENRIETTA LACKS as he was discussing cell culture and Skloot was anxious to investigate. Her HeLa fascination started there, and continued throughout her graduate school studies in writing, as she contemplated researching and writing about Henrietta Lacks. Eventually, she put pen to paper and brought HeLa's story to light.The book is a wonderfully written, and in my opinion, smartly-paced piece of nonfiction. It does a masterful job of detailing Skloot's heavy involvement in the HeLa chaos that resulted from an unethical medical treatment on a poverty-stricken black woman from Virginia in 1951. If you decide to read this book, (and I really hope you do), in the first half of the narrative you will meet a lovely, sweet woman named Henrietta Lacks and discover that she is suffering from a particularly aggressive form of cervical cancer. Diagnosed at the tender age of 30, Henrietta's cancer spreads rapidly and cuts short her life in a tragic flash, leaving behind a husband, five children, and surrounding family members who eventually live in the upsetting wake of Henrietta's undisclosed, yet amazing contribution to science.(I dislike book reviews that give blow-by-blow, page-by-page details of the book; I want you to read the book, not just this review, so I refrain here from delving too deeply into the scientific material you will find in the book.) I do want to reassure any ambivalent readers that this is an incredibly entertaining science book, without being overly scientific or stuffy in any way! It is very accessible to readers of all scientific knowledge, and will most definitely appeal to people who know absolutely nothing about cellular biology and cell cultures. (It explains things along the way). I started this book hoping the information would not go right over my head, and I'm pleased to say that none of the concepts escaped me intellectually. From a scientific perspective, Skloot has written an informative history of the HeLa cells, and that alone makes this book rewarding.However, I must say that the human element of the book is the author's number one achievement. Meeting the Lacks family members, one by one, and learning of their daily lives and coping mechanisms was even more interesting to me than the amazing science behind the HeLa phenomenon. Once you absorb and process the initial shock in the first half of the book of how radical HeLa cells truly are, you begin to settle into a second half of the narrative that just grabs your heart and doesn't let go until the last page. Skloot skips back and forth in time, and it was an interesting way to tell the story. We have a few chapters detailing events in 1951 when Henrietta was alive and in the thick of her illness, and then we flash forward to 1999 and onward to events in the author's life as she makes connections with the Lacks family and begins her very hands-on research. (Personally, I didn't find the structure detracting in any way; I felt that it kept the HeLa history very rooted and upfront in the successive decades and chapters, therefore not allowing the reader to lose sight of the very real woman and family behind the science and medical discoveries.)Speaking further of the sincerely human element of the book, Deborah Lacks was my absolute favorite part of the book! (I won't go so far as to say that she overshadowed her mother in the narrative, but I admit that she really did manage to catapult me that much further into the story). The initial portrait of Henrietta Lacks begins the story, and when her daughter Deborah steps in later in the book, you really get the sense that Deborah is trying her damndest to resolve the chaos and confusion that factor so strongly in the book. Henrietta is no longer around to speak for herself, but her cells do much of the "talking" in this book, and Deborah's voice rings just as true and sincere as her mother's biological determinism.I'm going to wrap up here, because the longer I spend on this review, the longer you might spend reading about it instead of picking up the book! I strongly recommend that you find a copy of the audiobook of "The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks" by Rebecca Skloot narrated by Cassandra Campbell and Bahni Turpin. I read along and listened to this awesome recording and am so glad I did. I feel like the characters really came alive with this audiobook narration. The voices are very expressive, and I think you will enjoy it!

I'm not sure why it took me so long to get around to reading this book. I've had it on my shelf for years, and my daughter - who loves nonfiction - had read it and raved about it. But I'm a big believer in that some books just bide their time, waiting for the right moment, and perhaps this was true of this book. Just before reading this book, I saw the documentary Thirteenth, and I couldn't help but think of how Henrietta Lacks' family history is the living embodiment of the painful, tragic history of African Americans in the United States. Thirteenth traces the history of African Americans: from the 'official' end of slavery in January 31, 1865, when the Thirteenth Amendment to the Constitution abolished slavery except as a punishment for a crime, to the present day. It's an incredibly thought-provoking documentary and it makes the persuasive case that African Americans (or people of color, as they are usually referred to in the documentary) have never truly transcended their second-class citizen status. Every time one societal change is made, racism mutates (rather like a cancerous cell) to become a different and yet still malignant disease.Henrietta was born in Roanoke, Virginia on August 18, 1920. She was only four years old when her mother died giving birth to her 10th child. Henrietta was then raised by her grandfather, along with a slightly older first cousin called 'Day'. They lived on a tobacco farm, and from an early age the children helped pick and cure the tobacco leaves. When Henrietta was 14, she became pregnant for the first time; Day was the father. By age 31, Henrietta was dead. She had given birth to 5 children, and died of cervical cancer after a swift and painful illness. (Henrietta had the most virulent form of the HPV virus, and a vaccine for this virus was made possible by the research done with her malignant cells.) I suppose there were countless women like Henrietta - women who had short and painful lives - but Henrietta's life has its own strange and unique immortality because she happened to be treated at Johns Hopkins Hospital, and her cancerous cells (now known as HeLa) have become the most famous and useful cells in human history.This book combines two different strands - one of them the medical advancements made possible by HeLa, and the other being the parallel existence of Henrietta's descendents. The fact that Henrietta Lacks was poor and black has nothing to do with her cells, but there is the vexed issue of medical experimentation being carried out on the vulnerable - and author Rebecca Skloot does a good job of contextualising this for the reader. Henrietta didn't knowingly contribute her body to the advancement of science, but the truth is that most of the amazing accomplishments and discoveries of the 20th century can be traced back to her cells. (There are many examples of this in the book, and you don't need an extensive knowledge of biology to understand Skloot's explanations.) Sadly, Henrietta's descendents have in no way benefited from the cash cow of HeLa and their collective story was absorbing and rather heartbreaking. The heart of the story is Deborah - a daughter who never knew her mother - and whose long, painful quest to learn the truth of the HeLa cells is really a personal journey of finding her lost mother.This was a fascinating study of social history and I found it to be a completely absorbing read. I don't tend to think of nonfiction as 'unputdownable', but that is how I would describe this book.

Compelling and fascinating pageturner that weaves the unique and groundbreaking story behind the HeLa cells that have revolutionized medical science in the last century. Skloot puts a name, a face, and a rich family history around the cells of Henrietta Lacks, who the "immortal" cells were essentially stolen from in the 1950s after she started treatment for severe cervical cancer. Medical records, archival research, and oral history paint a vivid picture of the Lacks' family's struggles in 1950s Baltimore. Skloot tells the story first hand, as she meets the surviving members of the Lacks family, and becomes very close to Henrietta's youngest daughter, Deborah. The book details very painful events (specifically Henrietta's abysmal "care" in the hospital after her tumors were discovered, and the treatment of Henrietta's other daughter, Elsie, in the Home for the Negro Insane) in the Lacks' family history. Skloot travels to southern Virginia where Henrietta grew up, and where she is now buried. The personal side of the book is so captivating, and the way Skloot interweaves this story in with the scientific information is near seamless. It's very well-done and quite accessible for a non-scientific audience. I learned a lot about genetics and about the research that the famous HeLa cells have engendered. I particularly enjoyed the portion of the book when the researcher spent the day with Skloot and Deborah Lacks, explaining the true breakthroughs from the HeLa cell line. There is soome criticism (here on GoodReads as well) that the book spent too much time with the Lacks' descendants, but I would argue that this is a very important part of the book - noting that while the Jim Crow laws are not in place, and the legal system is more aware of scientific research and patient "rights", there have not been socioeconomic strides for science education and alleviation of poverty in these inner-city areas. Skloot provided a very important context to the story of HeLa by setting the scene with Deborah, Zecharia, Lawrence, and the "cousins" in rural Virginia. On a local note, it was very interesting to learn the details about the Lacks family and their history in the Baltimore region. I have lived near Baltimore (and even worked and took classes at the institution that plays a large - and unfortunate - role in this book) for years and did not know some of the things that were discussed. Even closer to home, I was moved, and saddened to learn about the tragedies that happened at the Crownsville hospital, which is near my parents' home, and where I went to high school. I didn't realize the full history of the institution. Very moving story, and it is highly recommended.

Henrietta Lacks was a poor Southern woman and mother of five children who died in 1951 as the result of a remarkably aggressive form of cervical cancer. While undergoing radiation treatment, doctors at Johns Hopkins took samples of her cells without her consent, to better study the cancer. These cells, known as HeLa, became an important scientific and medical tool—they were the first "immortal" human cells grown in culture, and they are still alive today. HeLa cells were vital for developing the polio vaccine; uncovered secrets of cancer, viruses, and the atom bomb’s effects; helped lead to important advances like in vitro fertilization, cloning, and gene mapping; and have been bought and sold by the billions. But very little was known about the woman from whom these cells came, and her family was unaware of Henrietta's contributions to science for many, many years. The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks tells Henrietta's story and chronicles the struggles of her family, most of whom never had the opportunity to even finish high school, to understand what cells were taken from her and what scientists were doing with them. Rebecca Skloot also gives a great deal of background into scientific research, particularly where cell and tissue study is concerned, and the challenges both the scientific and medical ethics communities face relative to "donations" of cells taken from patients. But in the end, this is the story of Henrietta's family and the emotions that the discovery of her role in science uncovers. While the subject of this book is very scientific, much of it reads like a novel. It is a fantastic story—sometimes shocking, sometimes heartbreaking—but Skloot gives depth not only to Henrietta and her family, but the researchers who both studied and questioned the HeLa cells through the years. When this book was released last year to tremendous acclaim, I didn't think it would interest me much, but a friend recently recommended it, and I'm glad I was motivated to pick it up. Don't be put off by the subject matter; in the end, this will pique your curiosity and tug at your heart. And you'll definitely look with a different eye at the next medical procedure you have!

An important story, well-told by Rebecca Skloot, this book is about Henrietta Lacks and her cancerous cells that are known as the HeLa line. In 1951, Henrietta Lacks was a poor, uneducated black woman living with her husband and five young children in Baltimore when she developed cervical cancer and soon died. Without her knowledge or consent, cells from her cancer were cultured, distributed, and used in thousands of experiments continuing to this day, including pivotal developments in research about polio, radiation exposure, cancer, and more. The book successfully juxtaposes scientific information about the cells with the story of Henrietta's family and their fractured relationship with the medical establishment. The family was hounded by researchers who wanted DNA samples, without ever explaining what it was all about or offering any medical treatment to Henrietta's children who cope with multiple chronic diseases and no health insurance. Angry at what she sees as arrogant white doctors' appropriation of her mother, Henrietta's daughter Deborah asks, "If our mother cells done so much for medicine, how come her family can't afford to see no doctors?" The experiences of another family member, a developmentally disabled daughter called Elsie, reveal even more disturbing truths about the medical treatment of African Americans in the recent past.While the science and history aspects of this book are worthwhile, what makes the book really engaging is the human story about Deborah coming to terms with these terrible discoveries. When I read The Help, I was disturbed by what I saw as that white author's attempt to insert herself into a heroic role in the story, rescuing the black characters and earning their gratitude. This book could easily fall into the same trap, but Skloot lets Deborah take center stage and shows when Deborah is angry or mistrustful of her. Skloot may lead Deborah to some of the facts about Henrietta and Elsie, but the accomplishment of processing them is all Deborah's.

Reads as easily as a novel, but is non-fiction. Makes science accessible and interesting and tells the story of the Lacks family easily and honestly. A sometimes painful story, punctured with humor and emotion balanced by impeccable research into medical history. If you have not read it, I would highly recommend it.Sometimes I could not put it down and other times I had to put it down to digest either the raw emotions sometimes described or to absorb my reactions to the medical progress and medical ethics presented. Sometime the facts made me mad, other times it just amazed me how far we have progressed. I think I understood even more of the suspicion of poor, black families have of white, educated scientists and reporters. It made me angry but gave me a deeper understanding of the great gulf that has been created by procedures that took place at the time of Ms. Lacks cancer treatments on then use of her cells.

This book is amazing, being pretty well written and very interesting, and in addition, raising so many questions and issues related to research and our rights for our cells and tissues. Henrietta Lacks and her family's story is fascinating, and the topic as a whole still have many open questions.It would be an understatement to say that Henrietta Lacks is one of the most important people in science. The cells that were taken from her cervical cancer, are called HeLa and were used to develop the polio vaccine; uncovered secrets of cancer, viruses, and the atom bomb’s effects and so much more. Henrietta did not get a thank you, neither her family get recognition (or a medical insurance), she did not even get a marked grave. No permission was asked to use these cells, and not for commercializing them. People do not own the waste of their tissues, especially not poor colored people, right? Henrietta's cancer killed her very young, and left her children motherless. But science wouldn't be the same without her, and she lived through her cells helping to make giant progress.As Charles Dickens said at the beginning of [A] Tale of Two Cities, ‘It was the best of times, it was the worst of times.’ But it was the best of times for science in that this very peculiar tumor gave rise to the HeLa cell line. … For Mrs. Lacks and the family she left behind, it was the worst of times. Scientific progress and indeed progress of all kinds is often made at great cost, such as the sacrifice made by Henrietta Lacks.Many scientists worked daily with HeLa cells, and didn't know or asked themselves where did these come from, and what is the story behind these important cells.He’d been working with HeLa cells daily his whole career, he said, and now he couldn’t get the story of Henrietta and her family out of his mind. Henrietta's daughter, Deborah, that lost her mother very young was furious. She did not know what exactly happened to her mother, or what is being done with her cells. She was rightly mad that her story, or even the recognition should be widely known. She was afraid, and being not very educated and going through very hard life, was paranoid from anybody that tried to talk to her about her mother, her medical files, or anything else related to it.“You know they shot my mother cells into space and blew her up with nuclear bombs? They even did that thing … what do you call it … um … cloning! … that’s right, they did that cloning on her.”... “You wouldn’t believe it,” she said. “You know they mixed her with mice to make a human-mouse? They say she’s not even human anymore!” She laughed a loud, manic laugh and ran to the window. “Holy cuss!”  But Deborah's fears weren't completely irrational. In the past black people were considered dispensable, their bodies were used for research, as they were slaves. And the Ku Klux Klan actually started as a threatening technique to prevent them from escaping from their owners. (I recommend The Warmth of Other Suns: The Epic Story of America's Great Migration by Isabel Wilkerson to see how much more black people had to be afraid of, such as lynching). Just imagine trying on them surgical techniques without using anesthesia.Some of the stories were conjured by white plantation owners taking advantage of the long-held African belief that ghosts caused disease and death. To discourage slaves from meeting or escaping, slave owners told tales of gruesome research done on black bodies, then covered themselves in white sheets and crept around at night, posing as spirits coming to infect black people with disease or steal them for research. Those sheets eventually gave rise to the white hooded cloaks of the Ku Klux Klan. But night doctors weren’t just fictions conjured as scare tactics. Many doctors tested drugs on slaves and operated on them to develop new surgical techniques, often without using anesthesia. Fear of night doctors only increased in the early 1900s, as black people migrated north to Washington, D.C., and Baltimore, and news spread that medical schools there were offering money in exchange for bodies. Black corpses were routinely exhumed from graves for research, and an under ground shipping industry kept schools in the North supplied with black bodies from the South for anatomy courses. The bodies sometimes arrived, a dozen or so at a time, in barrels labeled turpentine.Prisoners were also a population that was under the threat of inhumane experiments on human beings. In some cases, they even signed up for the research, without really understanding what it means. Some would say that these are pretty similar to what the Nazis did. Cancer cell injections to inmates is just one exmaple of taking advantage of uneducated captured people for the good of science. Unimaginable in our world today that tries to prevent research on animals. Southam gave multiple cancer cell injections to each prisoner, and unlike the terminally ill patients, those men fought off the cancer completely. And with each new injection, their bodies responded faster, which seemed to indicate that the cells were increasing the inmates’ immunity to cancer. When Southam reported his results, the press hailed them as a tremendous breakthrough that could someday lead to a cancer vaccine. In the coming years, Southam injected HeLa and other living cancer cells into more than six hundred people for his research, about half of them cancer patients. He also began injecting them into every gynecologic surgery patient who came to Sloan-Kettering’s Memorial Hospital or its James Ewing Hospital. If he explained anything, he simply said he was testing them for cancer. And he believed he was: Since people with cancer seemed to reject the cells more slowly than healthy people did, Southam thought that by timing the rejection rate, he might be able to find undiagnosed cases of cancer.Coming back to the human right on the human body. Legislation around our user data, our documents etc is very advanced today. But what about our right for our cells and genes? Some claims about asking permission exclaimed that it would be against the progress of science, that it is just a human waste and therefore people don't have the right for it anymore. But it is probably not their place to decide, and the world is marching to defend people rights wherever it comes up. HIPAA (Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act) is a good start to fix the problems that still exist in this field.And there is a bright side, and Henrietta is an example that one person can have a giant impact on the world. Without education, money, or too much luck, she succeeded to get science to great breakthroughs.he pointed around the room at Davon and JaBrea’s other cousins, saying, “So will that child … and that child … and that child. This is their story now. They need to take hold of it and let it teach them they can change the world too.”5 stars for a woman bigger than life, and an important historical evolvement in an ever changing world.

If I could give this book 10 stars, I would. It is an amazing story of Henrietta Lacks, whose cervical cancer cells became the first "immortal" cells in the study of human cell cultures. It covers the story of her life, death, and how her cells have changed science as we know it. In 1951, it was common for tissue to be taken without a patient's knowledge, especially when the patient was black. This book touches on how that simple fact changed a family's life. Much of the book discusses how it effected Henrietta's children once they found out that their mother's tumor had been taken and experimented on without her consent during the biopsy of the tumor. Upon her death, consent was given for an autopsy and some samples to be taken, but it was because her husband wasn't fully informed and thought that the tests would detect whether his and Henrietta's children had cancer.The book also discusses race issues and class issues that have touched the Lacks family's life. It discusses what care was common for black people in the early 50s and how many black people didn't get basic health care because they simply couldn't afford it and because it was well-known that black patients were often experimented on. It's heartbreaking to read about her family's complete misunderstanding of what had been done to their mother. When Henrietta's children were told about the fact that Henrietta's cells were still alive and being studied, 25 years after her death, they first thought that their mother had been kept alive all that time and was being experimented on. This wasn't because they were intellectually unable to understand it (as shown by how Deborah, Henrietta's surviving daughter, taught herself a lot of the science surrounding the testing done on the cell line established from Henrietta's cell sample), but because they were so poor that they weren't given basic science education and because of the lingering taint on the medical establishment that remained due to the Tuskegee airmen experiment and similar experiments. It's also heartbreaking to read about the fact that the Lacks' family had, at the time of the publishing of the book, no health insurance, even though their mother's cells have been sold and resold uncountable times.The race issues are also discussed when it comes to the care of Elsie, who was institutionalized when Henrietta became ill, because she was significantly developmentally disabled. Unfortunately, Elsie's life wasn't as well-documented as Henrietta's life, and many of her medical files were lost between the time of her death and when Skloot and Deborah begin their research into Elsie's life. But it's made clear that experiments were done on Elsie without the family's consent and that it was quite common at the time for experiments to be done on those in mental institutions.Lastly, this book touches on how the issue of the ownership of tissues taken for samples and payment for any treatments or cures to the owner of the tissues is evolving. As of right now, once you sign away the rights to your tissue, you sign away the monetary rights, but the law is still trying to find the "right" answer to this issue.I cannot recommend this book enough. Even if you're not interested in the scientific aspect of it, it's a book that should be read for the human side of the story, along with the medical ethics issues. I'll end with saying that there are some triggery things in this book, especially if you have issues surrounding medical things being done to you without your consent. But I think that should go without saying. Everything is handled as sensitively as possible, though. I found that the matter-of-fact matter in which Skloot writes makes it all a bit harder to digest, especially if you're very unused to these things being discussed so openly. But I think that style suits this story -- the things that happened to this family should make you uncomfortable.

This book was excellent and I found myself totally drawn into Henrietta's story right from the first few pages. Rebecca Skloot is a journalist with a keen interest in discovering the truth behind the HeLa cells, the infamous cells that multiplied faster than any others in culture and made dozens of new scientific break-throughs possible. These cells were taken from Henrietta Lacks, a black woman diagnosed with cervical cancer, when she was being treated, without her knowledge, and long after her death they continue to be used world-wide. What I loved about this story was the raw personable tone to the writing. This book fully deserved to win the Wellcomebookprize in my eyes, becuase it was truly a wonder of storytelling, fact and fiction all wonderfully blended. Skloot manages to tell us the important details of science in a way that feels approachable and easy, whilst also showing the raw side of the deal that the Lacks family ended up with, and the emotional connection she herself had with the daughter of the family. This is truly a story that more people need to learn about and experience. A beautiful book, an informative piece of writing, and a very deserved winner of the prize in my eyes. Excellent, 4.5*s

mp3 ontheroadIt seems that many of my online friends rate this book highly and an hour in, I can say this is interesting. I find the hit and miss care of Jim Crow era black care particularly disturbing/enraging. Wow! I have just been side-reading about this flake...Alexis Carrel

Such a profound book that was fascinating on so many levels: science, medicine, human interest, racism, and family. I have so many thoughts about this book I need to collect them before I write a proper review. Highly recommend.

This book has already been lauded and reviewed to the moon and to the garbage can, which is where I think it should go. The story, as Skloot tells it, has already been told in articles and, briefly, in another book, but Skloot feels called to tell it again. Unfortunately, this is the very public story of a private individual and her family who have never consented to any of this and are tired of white people turning up on their doorstep looking for inside information. Skloot acknowledges this without stopping and finding a new hobby.Here's a far from complete list of problems with this book:So little science. It's written for your aunt's book club, but with Skloot's litany of, "HeLa cells have been sent into space, blown up in an atom bomb, fought AIDS, etc," I would like to know how HeLa cells helped create bombs, for example. There's a little bit about cell reproduction and a little about the creation of the polio vaccine, but anything is exciting is when its blasted into space. Please explain how this was done. Use simple words. Use metaphors. But don't just say, "Science happened."My other problems are tied racism, mostly Skloot's. She drives through a Black Baltimore neighborhood for over an hour looking for a store without stopping because [stopping to ask black people for directions is scary]. She keeps waving at the same men. Children are running after her car. And she seeks a church for sanctuary.Formal address. Henrietta Lacks' children call Skloot "Miss Rebecca." (http://ask.metafilter.com/224268/Sout...) Skloot calls Henrietta Lacks and her relatives by their first names. Doctors and scientists are called by their last names.Mrs. Lacks' daughter Deborah makes an expository statement on doctors kidnapping and doing medical experiments on Blacks. Skloot explains at length why the medical establishment was not actually kidnapping Black people for the purpose of medical experimentation. Skloot does mention Tuskegee and some other documented incidents of non-consensual, fatal medical experiments; and later she and Deborah go to the Hospital for the Negro Insane, where Deborah's sister had horrific medical experiments performed on her. The kidnapping of Black people (Fugitive Slave Act, lynching, etc.) should be well known. But Skloot needs to refute, at length, Deborah's conflation of kidnapping and medical experiments. Aaargh! It is not up to the oppressed to determine which people are kidnapping them and which people are doing horrific medical experiments and then make the distinction between the two groups in casual conversation.And Skloot's treatment of Deborah in general. Skloot seems genuinely impressed by Deborah's research on HeLa cells, but she never goes so far as to help her, or connect her with a lawyer to look into the legitimacy of a suit against, say, Johns Hopkins for releasing Mrs. Lacks' medical records without consent. Skloot refuses to give a percentage of book sales to Mrs. Lacks' descendants directly, instead creating a scholarship fund of which she is the gatekeeper. And the last day Skloot and Deborah travel together, Skloot's describes Deborah's crazy, manic behavior as though it was a consistent with Deborah's normal self, even though Skloot learns the next day that Deborah was having a major medical episode that caused her to act erratically. The writing is bad. The progression of HeLa research through the Cold War era is appropriately chronological. But when Skloot comes on the scene, she describes everything in the order it happened to her, instead of pulling it together coherently and making it less of a travelogue into the lives of the Black people she was badgering.Also, Bahni Turpin does all the Black voices on the audiobook and another person reads the rest of the text. That might be an allegorical manifestation of the book itself. The white person speaks at length and freely, while the Black characters are handed a representation bone.

I remember the first time I heard of Henrietta and her family's story; like Skloot, it was as a brief aside during a biology class and, like Skloot, it affected me much more than the teacher seemed to think it should. When I heard about Skloot's book, I was very interested.Unfortunately, Skloot's book's a bit of a mess, and the material itself makes the reasons why pretty clear. The idea has been gestating for at least 10 years, and she's probably been writing for at least five; she clearly had dozens of directions she wanted to go with the book - mainly, though, detailing the story of a wronged southern black family and talking about the injustices of the old South and telling the story of a cell line which have had a profound impact on science. Unfortunately, these two don't tie together in any significant way, and Skloot, probably because she spent so much time with the family and envisioned this book as a science-based human interest story, emphasizes, to the book's detriment, the human interest part (it may well be because - and I don't know because I don't know much about it - people familiar with science know of many accounts of the actual history of HeLa cells). To the point where we are finding out details of the lives of many of Henrietta's cousins and children and grandchildren, which just make the narrative a complete mess.Henrietta's story, too, is not particularly ethically complicated; she received what was proper treatment, and, though the biopsy was performed without her approval, it hardly added any pain to her situation, there was no malicious intent from the doctors, and indeed Skloot talks at one point about how little interest Gey, the scientist who originally worked with her cells, had in profit and instead how much he cared about the advancement of science at the expense of his own potential for patents, etc.Her narrative of the history of cell culture is interesting, but the science is massively toned down. She also tries to include silly stuff about religion v. science - she mentions some thoughts a little bit at the book's very beginning, but it disappears until the very end, at which point she has not at all established it as any sort of important consideration in this story.And, I really don't mean to go into ad hominem attacks here - Skloot seems well-intentioned and liberal-minded - but I feel that Skloot inserted herself into the story far too much. Like, with the whole storyline culminating in Deborah finally letting her look at the medical records, she seemed to paint herself as some sort of redeemer of all the prior sins against the Lacks family which she spent so long detailing. One particularly bizarre scene is when Deborah and her grandchildren ride to see Zakariyya (p. 242 in my version), and the grandchildren, whom Skloot described as "strkingly beautiful" say to Skloot both "I love you" and "You're mine." These eight lines could be stricken from the book without losing, you know, anything at all, but Skloot, a writing teacher, should know that every detail should be in a narrative for a reason. What is the reason here? It's strange. Why does she insist we see how much she is loved by the children, especially in this flirtatious way?

This is a book that EVERYBODY needs to read. The individuals in this books are real life people who have had a grave injustice done to their family. While the content will most likely leave readers feeling a whole range of emotions from sadness to anger, the actual content of this book is something that needs to be read by all people regardless of color, age, or background. While there are parts of the story that seem exploitative (I honestly felt as if Skloot sometimes went into too much detail about different parts of the Lacks' family's dysfunction when describing individuals who are currently living), the overall story of Henrietta Lacks' body being defiled and her cells taken without her or her family's consent all in the name of science is something that everyone should read up on.

I had several simultaneous thoughts as I read this book:1. I hope the Lacks family gets some of the money from this book. There's been a lot of profit derived from them that has never reached them.2. THIS is how you tell a story. It's not contrived. It's complex. She doesn't tell us what to think (that much), but lays out the story in such a way that your own thoughts and emotions fill that last crucial gap. 3. I'm so grateful for HELA. Man, thank God for science!4. I was a bit uncomfortable with the way Skloot characterized the family. There was warmth and tenderness, but also a bit of exotification or "otherness" to the way she covered them. 5. Having watched Get Out, I thought about this story differently

Summer Reading Book #2 (IB Theory of Knowledge)For a summer reading book, it was pretty dang good! I loved how Rebecca Skloot combined the scientific and familial aspects of this book to make a work of non-fiction seem like it was a fiction novel. Also, she included her own personal aspects, showing her struggle through the research process and learning about Henrietta's family. I personally think that science and medicine is fascinating (as I want to study either pediatrics or dermatology), so I am very glad that I was required to read this book for school as it exposed me to HeLa cells and both the impact that they made on the scientific community and on Henrietta Lack's family.

The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks by Rebecca Sklool is an important read about the famous HeLa cells, that contributed to many science advancements. It is a science driven novel about Henrietta and her family. Poor, uneducated and black, Henrietta was kind, giving and loving to her children. Her tragic death and her children's fate are emotional.Before reading this book, I personally did not know about these cells or Henrietta. It is a meticulously researched book and thought provoking but at times too long and unfocused.

HeLa is an obscure topic for most readers. Science writing is a difficult topic for most readers. Skloot's narative is superb with just the right blend of information, human interest and drama. The HeLa cells were (and are) the key to many breakthroughs in disease (starting with polio). This study covers the researchers as well as Henrietta Lacks (the donor) and the plight of the family who dealt with her loss and the outside world that failed them in many ways.

An important book someone had to write and the author is quite capable of telling the story. Meticulously researched, she presents a scientific dilemma and problems when technology surpasses moral/ethical obligations.

What a wasted opportunity to learn some real history of cell lines. Particularity the importance of the HeLa line. This book goes in too many different directions, and is way too long. There could have been such a good book here as the topic is fascinating. I wish I hadn't wasted my time.

The parts about Henrietta's life were interesting but unbearably sad. Her suffering was awful. I didn't find the science or legal rights or wrongs interesting. An important story. I wonder how this book will affect her family?
I thought this was excellent. Audio was a great way to consume this story.

I teach an Introduction to Clinical Medicine course in a medical school and this book was a summer reading assignment. The class spent last Wednesday discussing and debating the book and I was grateful to discover that many of the students in the class felt the same way I did - they really disliked this book. I've summarized many of the reasons why the students and I developed such strongly negative opinions of "The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks" here:1. The author has created a mythology. By referring to Henrietta somehow being "alive" is falacious. The cells are not Henrietta - in fact they are the opposite of Henrietta. The cells are anti-Henrietta and are what actually killed her. Do you cry and worry over the hair that's left on the floor of a barbershop after a haircut? How about your nail clippings? What about baby teeth or a wart that is burned off? What is,the difference between any of these things and Henrietta's cells? The family were uneducated and superstitious and to continuously refer to the cells and somehow "being" Henrietta was a confusing and cruel fantasy.2. Why did the author inject herself into the story? Is that what historical biographers are supposed to do? Frankly, the only part of the book that isn't salacious, pandering, Jerry Springer-level anthropology is the 13 page Afterword, which is actually a well-written and thought-provoking essay. Now Ms. Skloot is forever linked to this pseudo-story, not as an objective observer but as a character in her own fevered imagination. It is a tremendous effort at self-promotion and glory-seeking which throws a dark shadow over the believability of any of the events of the story. 3. The author creates many 2-dimensional characters that are either all good or all bad. Cases in point- the elderly couple with the Confederate flags in the living room, Galen the sexual-predator uncle and Christoph, the noble and sympathetic scientist. 4. The author makes transparent attempts to link totally disparate events so that they seem to have something in common and almost cause and effect. Example - the descriptions of injecting the prisoners with cancer cells and the Nazi experiments (Chapter 17) can only remotely, peripherally be construed as having ANYTHING to do with HeLa cells. It's comparing apples to oranges and these conversations have no place in this book. 5. The family seem to expect that they are owed something because they are recipients of a genetic lottery ticket by their (in many cases) tenuous associations with Henrietta's DNA. For example - her husband Day can arguably be described as the person responsible for Henrietta's cancer, as he was the person most likely to have infected her with syphilis and HPV - why should he or any of the other extended family financially benefit from the hard work of the geneticists and scientists that developed the successful cell cloning techniques?6. The whole Lacks family are depicted as intellectual children and borderline retarded.7. Why did the author use the convention to colloquialize the speech of the minority characters (the Lacks and Susan Hsu the Chinese lab assistant) but not any of the other foreign characters? Christoph Lengauer was born and raised in Austria. He studied human genetics/biology at the Unviersity of Salzburg, Austria. Dr. Lengauer received his PhD from the University of Heidelberg, Germany and went for his postdoctoral studies to the IMP (Institute of Molecular Pathology) in Vienna, Austria. He then joined the group of Prof. Bert Vogelstein at the Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine. I cannot believe that Dr. Lengauer doesn't speak with an accent, yet the author elected NOT to colloquialize his speech or any of the other non-minority characters. This was probably the single most offensive thing about this book. It is condescending, sanctimonius, patronizing and probably racist.8. Why is Zakariyya depicted as a sympathetic figure? He is a murderer, a drunk and a violent societal parasite. Compare this with the depiction of the fake lawyer (Cofield). I'm not fan of lawyers, but as far as we know, Cofield never killed anyone. Why is Cofield a terrible, albeit bumbling villain, yet Zakariyya is someone that deserves sympathy and pity? These were some of the main points that came out in our discussion. Some of the students initially said that they enjoyed the book and they "felt sorry for the family", but once we actually began teasing apart the numerous problems with the novel, every student agreed that what we read was not the story of Henrietta Lacks or of HeLa cells, but instead the story of Rebecca Skloot and her naked ambition for fame.
This book was wonderful! It was so eloquently written and informative. I feel like I was there while Ms Skloot was with Deborah and everyone. Extremely well written!
Terrific!

For a non-fiction book, this reads really well. The research is written in a way that is accessible to a reader who may be unfamiliar with the subject (like me...science is not my favorite thing to read about). And of course the human element of the story and discussion of ethics and moral obligation in science is well worth the read.

This book was awesome!! I love medical stuff and I love learning about things like this. This book was about a black woman who’s cells were taken without her information and she died from cancer that was all over her body. This book talks about her childhood, while she was going through treatment, after she died, and what happened to her family afterward. Because of her cells we are able to have the vaccines and other things in the medical field because of her. Her family doesn’t get any of the money that the multi-million dollar medical industry makes, even though most of what has been discovered was because to her cells. The fight for justice with her cells is still going on today in courts.

It was such a great story I was sure I was going to give it a 5. Then I entered the last 1/4 of the book and realized what a despicable person authored the book and gave it one star. I thoroughly enjoyed both the science, dilemmas, and human aspects of the story and I am very sorry it was not told by someone who was decent. Although feigning objectivity throughout it was obvious by the end that it was anything but. This author took advantage of this family for financial gain in a way much worse than any scientific research company. She spent an extensive amount of time convincing them they should trust her and she was on their side.-This was largely an biography of Deborah; and unbeknownst to her. She should have been compensated as such. The author told Deborah that she could not compensate her and would have to set up a scholarship fund for her instead. Deborah believed her because she trusted her and it did not occur to her that Rebecca Skloot had no right to decide that this family could not decide how to spend their money themselves and also figure out how to compensate them.-On page 267 she wrote her observations of Henrietta's sister Glady's upon having been invited into her private residence. Glady's was wheelchair bound and it was stated she was crippled by arthritis to the point that her chest was resting nearly on her knees. When the people came into the room this old woman trapped in a wheelchair is reported to have had her nightgown up around her waist and struggling to pull it down. Rebecca Skloot chose to forever strip her of the dignity she was desperately attempting to preserve by relating it in detail. Utterly despicable. -The accounts of Deborah's erratic behavior became lengthy and actually tedious the last 1/4 of the book. (It is an example of her lack of objectivity and there are many.) It is obvious the author meant to portray her in this way at that time. Rebecca Skloot was hanging on until she got Deborah to give her Henrietta's medical records. At this part of the book Deborah had given them to her and had nothing more she desired and her relating of her 'object' changed.-She accomplished nothing in pursuing these people in such an extreme way but her own profits. In the end the statement of one of the Lack's men was identical to what it had always been. They still did not know why they could not even afford health care if HELA had done so much to revolutionize healthcare and they wanted to educate their children in these matters so they would not be hurt like they were. (others pursuing them because Henrietta is HELA) There is no reason on Gods green earth why the Lacks cannot have those very reasonable things. Perhaps Ms. Skloot would like to see to it that happens starting with the profits from this book.-I cannot stand what this author did to Deborah in the end. She related such deeply personal details about Deborah's state of health and mental health that support much of the hyperbole already surrounding this family that it is she they should sue.-She violated the trust of Deborah in disclosing the personal medical records of her little sister. This was apparently an enormous struggle and the author relates extensive distressed conversation with Deborah extracting promises not to tell. She gave just as many extensive promises that she would not. Instead she related that young people institutionalized there were not separated by age or sex and that they endured sexual abuse. It is easy to figure out what Deborah was trying to protect her little sister and her dignity about. Ms. Skloot decided to violate that agreement as well as the trust of Deborah and trick her. Despicable.

This book represents, to me, much of what is wrong is pop non-fiction. The author was far too present throughout the entire book, and the book itself is a much more about her and her obsession with Henrietta Lacks than it is about anything else. White guilt and righteous indignation were two main themes pervading much of the writing. The narrative was all over the place, and at the end of the book, I couldn't tell why it had been written. To educate about inequalities of health care? (not really, the issue was never actually discussed in anything but a hyper-emotional way) To honor Henrietta Lacks? (not really--her person and character disappears after a few chapters) To explain what HeLa cells are for?
