To me, that makes the book much better than if she'd tried to maintain false distance from the less famous Lackses, She treats them with the dignity that was so lacking in how HeLa came to be, and you can really feel that in the writing. The afterward is an interesting look at tissue rights that is only as effective as it is in relation to booth halves do the book. I came away feeling both educated and moved, and while it may not be for everyone I personally found it to be fascinating.

This is the most gut-wrenching non-fiction book I've read to date in 2017. "The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks" dealt with the 'shady'/unethical practices of how John Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore, Maryland stole while harvested the 'immortal' cells of Henrietta Lacks without her or her family's consent.The year was 1951 when colored woman, Loretta Pleasant aka Henrietta Lacks was diagnosed with cervical cancer, treated and died on October 4th yet her durable and immortal cells: HeLa cells relentlessly thrived secretly due to Dr. Gey unprincipled medical practices. This is a must read for all readers interested in how Lacks' cells have been used to save lives from diseases ranging from Jonas Salk's Polio vaccine, cancers, HIV/AID, and even man's space frontiers as well as developing various anti-tumor medicines. Truly an amazing scientific story that makes you question how far doctors have gone to make a name for their scientific professions using unethical and unscrupulous practices.5+++ stars

I've read a lot of panicked blogs lately by authors who feel that the novel is dead and non-fiction is a far more vital form. While I don't agree with that statement, this book would certainly be an argument for it. In the acknowledgements, the author thanks a bookstore owner who brought her novels with non-linear structures as she tried to figure out how to structure her own book; I think it's telling that she would look to fiction to construct her narrative. While the chapters about medical ethics are fascinating, it is the travails of Henrietta Lacks' family members that make the book so captivating. Henrietta Lacks, the woman whose cells are still dividing under microscopes across the globe, finally has a eulogy to go with her name. Hopefully this book makes up for some of the wrongs done to her family.

Others have summarized the key points of this book better than I could. It's a fascinating story weaving so many different skeins, as it veers between Henrietta's story, the work of the scientists studying her cells, the fate of Henrietta's family, and the author herself. A secondary mystery in the book concerns Henrietta's oldest daughter... what was wrong with her and what happened to her? When you find out, it's devastating emotionally - and also a damning indictment of the institutions that treated poor black people as subhuman.This book blew my mind. It also kind of broke my heart.

3.5 stars. Skloot has done amazing research: 20+ page bibliography, 10 pages of acknowledgments, but the book suffers from trying to do too much. It is a profile of Henrietta Lacks, whose cancer cells were the first to survive outside the body and have been used by many thousands of research scientists for 60+ years, and her surviving family. It also takes a look at the moral and ethical issues around using human tissue, and the controversy about Henrietta's cancer cells, including how big pharma can profit while her family lives in relative poverty. I felt the 2-3 story lines were incongruous, making the book disjointed.

I've been sick and not keeping up with books online and listened to this during that period.I initially didn't add a review because I have such mixed feelings about this book.The research is impeccable and I appreciate the access to this story. At the same time I feel uncomfortable in a way with how the author handled her interactions with the family. They rubbed me the wrong way. I've since done some research and found perhaps the author did cross the line a bit with the family.That leaves me feeling differently about the book as a whole. Important information gained in a manner not handled as respectfully by the author as it should've been?

I very much enjoyed this read. I think my experience at Goodreads has broadened me, into picking things up that I might not have - and non-fiction is never an easy choice for me. This book satisfies three challenges for me this month, but it was also just enjoyable to read. I really loved, as how Deborah/Dale was searching for how to narrate her experience, the answer really became quite spiritual and pure for her. It was beautiful to see that play out - and through the siblings and narrator as well. It was well done. Speaking of spiritual, now starting the God of Small Things.

A wonderful journalist exploration of the cross over between human relationships and scientific progress, this book explores how the pursuit of prolonging lives interacts with human nature and real people. This book is well written, engaging, and extensive. Perhaps there are some facts unnecessary to many readers, but this is a highly useful case study on the effects on an entire family of the cost and benefits of scientific progress.

Interesting read, glad I did it. Makes you question science and doctors and think about how rough others have it and how primitive health care used to be. Some of the experiments that were done are cringe worthy. Definitely makes me want to always get second or even third opinions when it comes to health. Of course the main question though is, would you give consent and give up your tissues or parts of your body for research?

Reading about 4 or 5 non-fiction books a month for years and years, this is one that in 2012- I think is appropriate for all. How this woman has changed so much, when her life was so short and really fairly brutal! Living through this period myself, and working in pharmacy- I doubt she is the only historic donor of some essence or knowledge. Unregarded for the most part, as well.

Too romanticized of a science book for my taste. However, worth reading to know about African Americans and their contributions to medicine, as well as the poverty their families still face today.Donate to Henrietta Lacks Foundation here.

HeLa is one of the most commonly used cell lines in science research across the world. The cells derive from Henrietta Lacks. They were taken from her in 1951, the same year she died of cancer, without her consent or knowledge. This book details with clarity and compassion the astonishing story of Henrietta and her family. A remarkable book and a must-read.

I believe I was in a constant state of "goosebumps" as I learned about HeLa cells and the impact this one person and her cells have had on the rest of the world. Her story should be a part of every high school science curriculum.
I'll be reading this again in the future. The issues it raises are worth revisiting again and again. It's an important book.
This is now one of my all-time favorite books. Rebecca Skloot, I am in complete awe.
What an interesting read, very engaging. I think I felt every emotion known to man while reading this book.

3.5 starsNB Don't be fooled by my rating, this is an important book with a story that needed to be told, but I wasn't impressed by the actual writing. How much of this was the result of reading many rave reviews and expecting too much is difficult to say, but even without the hype, this wouldn't have had 5 stars from me.First off, THANK YOU to Henrietta Lacks' family and Rebecca Skloot for how we now have so much of this story, the good, the bad (the maybe) and the ugly. (but not nearly everything as you need to read the book to get much, much more!)Regarding the use of HeLa cells and cells in general:The ugly--the entire lack of ethics involved in American (and probably most of the world) medical and scientific research. True--African Americans have been mistreated for many, many years in this. Also true--they were taking samples from people of all races without permission, but Henrietta's were the first to work. But don't think that you get permission for your cells to be used for research today--once a body part or biopsy as been done, that is no longer legally yours. That said, if your body is to be used for scientific research, your permission is required.The bad--Henrietta's family was kept in the dark even after they started trying to get answers once they realized something was going on. (the maybe) - George Gey, who first took the cells without permission, as was commonly done, was doing it for altruistic purposes and freely gave the cells to other. You have to read the book to find out more.The good-- millions of lives have been saved as a result of research on HeLa, not to mention the many, many children who no longer become paralyzed from polio.Should you read this book? I think so.

This book makes me a bit grumbly. After a decent start recounting the life of Henrietta Lacks and the genesis of the HeLa cell line, I got bogged down in the middle section as it seemed to jump around a bit too much introducing a cast of thousands of scientists and Lacks. Then the third section seemed to be an entirely different book as the author ditched all pretense at objectivity and embedded herself into the Lacks family and their story.Having raised so many issues about ethics and remuneration for the Lacks family due to the profits so many have made from Henrietta's cell sample, Skloot seemed to turn the corner herself into exploitation as she fully inserted herself into the narrative. Much like tissue culture research, Skloot isn't legally obliged to pay the Lacks family a cent for their story. But once she mentions a scholarship fund she is setting up for the Lacks children's education, her book becomes part of the ethical quagmire she has been outlining for over 300 pages. She doesn't really mention what percentage of the book's earnings she is contributing to that fund, but I start thinking what would be ethical or fair or reasonable: 1%, 10%, 40%, more? How does one arbitrarily slap a number on something like this?In the end, this book is frustrating because it puts us in that gray area of what is ethical, what is legal, what is good for humanity as a whole, and what our gut tells us is fair for the individuals involved. There is no good answer to be had here, leaving me unsatisfied to the extreme.

There are several storylines in this book, making it quite complex to write an encompassing review. This review will therefore most likely not do the book justice. That said, I thought it was a remarkably well written, easy to follow along book. The science was well explained and wasn’t too complicated. For a non-fiction book, it had me go through a whole range of emotions I had not anticipated. The book tells the story of Henrietta Lacks, from whom the HeLa cells were obtained, and of Henrietta’s family. It’s a story of recognition, told with grace; a story both sad and uplifting. Rebecca Skloot puts it all into context, explaining the prevailing convictions during Henrietta’s lifetime, while not shunning the ugliness of racial injustice. She describes the many shameful practices carried out for the sake of medical research, but also how much knowledge we gained by using them. Not infrequently, I’d come across a paragraph that forced me to stop reading and take a few deep breaths, before I could continue. Eye-opening. Highly recommended.

Rebecca Skloot has set a new standard for evenhanded reporting, science journalism, and entertainment. Her decade of dedication, and gift of storytelling, has brought the story of Henrietta Lacks into the zeitgeist.

An interesting and a heartbreaking read. You get a bit of medical history, a family history, and a journalist's pursuit. the medical part was fascinating and it was easy to understand which is an A+.the family history was horrifying and just gut wrenching; the part about the asylum was so disturbing I had to take a break from reading it. an A+ to this part too.the Journalist part was good, a bit dull at some points but it helped in connecting the previous parts together. a B+ goes to this part. In short I'm glad I picked this one up, and I was surprised that I never gave it a glance before since the book has been going around for a long time in our bookstores. I guess it choose its own time to be read ~

Upon reading this book I felt cheated, not by this book but by all the science books I’ve read before it. I earned my first three science degrees (including my medical degree) in the late 1980’s early 1990’s, and at that point women’s contributions to science were barely acknowledged, regardless of race. I’m convinced the only reason we learned of Madam Curie was she won the Nobel Prize and couldn’t be ignored. I never heard of Rosalind Franklin and her contribution to DNA studies until an injury-forced career change took me back in pursuit of another science degree. I’m working up two new anatomy classes both of which have chapters on genetics and there is still not one mention of Hela or Henrietta (though there will be in my own notes).I’m not including the tooting of my own horn here just to brag but rather to point out my own background in science is extensive and to illustrate just how ignore Henrietta Lacks’s unknowing contribution to science still is so I am very glad to have this book (which will be going on the suggested reading list for my classes). To begin with I think Ms Skloot manages a difficult task, making non-fiction as easy to read and as compelling as fiction (Personally I often find non-fiction to be almost like work in reading it, too dry). Her passion for this story comes through so strongly and her care and concern for the Lackses is touching. She had more patience than most people would have and I commend her for it.She deftly weaves Henrietta and the family’s past in with the modern day search to bring the truth to the surface. Henrietta had a hard short life and the sad reality was in 1950’s America people of African descent had every reason to fear hospitals. Any number of studies was undertaken then that today are horrifying to the point many of my students can’t even believe that it happened when I tell them about things like the Tuskegee experiments. I know from personal experience with patients that would have been Henrietta’s contemporaries that no one, regardless of race, questioned doctors back then. None of the family would have known that her cells had been harvested and that is true today (points to the afterward, most people don’t realize that biological tissues are often used for study rather than destroyed. My surgery last month was purposely done at a teaching hospital so that both the surgery and the tissues taken could be used for research but there were no consent forms for that purpose as they’re still debating the pros and cons of such a thing).However, this, along with fears that their mother was purposely allowed to die, tainted several generations of the Lacks family. Ms Skloot had a lot of hard work to win their trust. The inarguable thing about the whole story is though, how revolutionizing Henrietta’s cancerous cervical cells really were. They were so successful in living in culture that they are still here today decades after Henrietta’s death. This immortality of her cells allowed for an incredible amount of research done, vaccinations, the effects of space travel and so much more.I was stunned at how hounded for information Henrietta’s descendants were (given how little I have ever seen about HeLa cells in text books. Professional articles are a different story). At least from Ms Skloot’s telling of it, Deborah, Henrietta’s daughter, and her siblings did seem to find a measure of peace through Skloot’s investigation which is good especially in how wronged they felt (and rightfully so).I’m not sure at all how I feel about some of the questions raised about today’s medical ethics (you can not go back and apply today’s HIPPA laws and patented cells lines to the days when the cells were first harvested). I’ve volunteered for medical research (but only very occasionally, women are rarely taken as research subjects unless it’s female related). Sometimes you’re paid, sometimes not. What would happen to science if there had to be a pay out to every volunteer? It’s a question not to be taken lightly. Would it bankrupt the whole system? Or, like in the case of the Lackses who have very little, would it be fair compensation. I don’t know the answer to that. I’m not sure anyone does. I know I’ve always been bothered by funeral homes making extraordinary sums for tissue harvesting for donations while the family sees none of it. Is this any different? I guess you’ll have to read the afterward of the book and wrestle with these questions yourself. I did find it very telling as to where humans put their priorities though when the book talks about animal rights in the lab getting protected in 1909 and we didn’t even start talking about humans in the same way until 50 years later and legislation wouldn’t follow for another couple decades. Anyhow, to sum up this rambling mix of review and personal experience, go read this book. If you have any interest in science research, social injustice and medical ethics, this is an absolutely fascinating book that will amaze, frustrate and infuriate you as you go along for the ride.

I had avoided this book due to slight disinterest but knowing I was going to get mad and the injustices. It was an interesting blend of history, science, and the author's experience as she learned about HELA and Henrietta's family.

This is one of the best nonfiction books that I have ever read. I can't recommend it enough. Rebecca Skloot took a footnote from a basic biology book (about the origin of HeLa cells) and turned it into an investigation into the origins of the HeLa cells, the woman behind those original cells, racism, medical ethics, scientific research, and the effect of the HeLa cells on both medicine and on the Lacks family. One of the most powerful threads of the book follows the story of Henrietta Lacks, a poor, African-American woman, who died of cancer in the early 1950s. Unknown to Henrietta, doctors at Johns Hopkins University Hospital in Baltimore, Maryland took samples of her initial tumor and, to their surprise, those cells were the first cells to stay alive and continue to develop and divide in the lab and HeLa cells are still alive almost 60 years after Henrietta's death. Using HeLa cells, medical researchers have been able to make amazing strides in research into polio, TB, Aids, and numerous other diseases. In fact, anyone who has seen a doctor since the second half of the 20th century has been impacted by medical research based on studies using HeLa cells. But that is only part of the story. Henrietta's family was never informed by doctors at Johns Hopkins about the importance of HeLa cells in medical research and when information began to leak out about the significance of these "immortal cells", the family was confused, angry, and suspicious. Rebecca Skloot is able to form a relationship with the children of Henrietta Lacks, especially her daughter, Deborah, that gradually leads the family into a greater understanding and appreciation of the place that their mother holds in medical history. One of the great strengths of this book is that the reader is able to understand how the many players in this story interacted or failed to interact with each other over decades. The author also has a gift--she is able to take complex scientific issues and write about them in a way that allows readers to understand the basic scientific principles involved. I only wish that someone like Rebecca Skloot taught some of the science classes that I have taken in the past. Finally, this book raises some important issues about medical ethics in America. Many readers will be struck by the fact that while valuable medical research would not have possible without HeLa cells, the fact also remains that many people have made millions of dollars from that research while the Lacks family was so poor that they were not able to afford medical insurance. Incidentally, the author has established a foundation for the benefit of Henrietta Lacks' family. This is a story that needed to be told and I am grateful that Rebecca Skloot told it.

Fascinating and mind-blowing! The eye-opening research surrounding Henrietta Lacks, HeLa cells, genetics, patient consent, privacy rights, and research ethics is quite evident, and Skloot is to be commended. Much of the information acquired didn't come easy. Ten-years researching and writing is a long-suffering investment, especially when opening a controversial, and often volatile, Pandora’s Box. People can be quite persnickety when it comes to their families, ethnicity, colleagues, and/or field of expertise being potentially perceived in a less-than-favorable light. However, Skloot did a relatively decent job presenting the objective and subjective even-handed and with empathetic-finesse. Additionally, though some of the medical terminology was a bit over my right-brained head, I greatly appreciated the book as a whole being layman-friendly. My two negative observations: 1. The chronological presentation is considerably fractured and jumpy at times and therefore information is sometimes repetitive. 2. In the dedication, only Skloot's family/friends are given notated named-honor. I thought it a little inconsiderate, not naming the Lacks family too, and/or mentioning any financial considerations towards the family. I would like to think the Lacks grandchildren benefited in some way from their mother's non-consensual donation to all of science. Overall, a great read for fans of biographies, cultural studies, medical history, or curious-topic-nonfiction. And a must read for anyone who’s ever had their blood drawn, or had a biopsy, or a mole removed, or appendectomy, or any other ‘ectomy.’ It’ll give you much to think about before your next doctor’s visit.

Rebecca Skloot does a great job researching the material for this book--one gets the feeling she could make anything interesting. It must have been a difficult book to write because of the yawning time lag and sketchy family and town histories. But Skloot manages to make the material immediate, fresh, and personal by introducing us to the Lacks clan, and by sharing with us her route to uncovering the science that makes Henrietta Lacks immortal. The sheer doggedness of her pursuit and the art involved in making the story not only readable, but riveting, is a good match for the best of science, much of which is healthy doses of perspiration with dashes of inspiration. I am pleased to see the book reach the bestseller lists, not simply because this is a story we all need to know, but because Skloot has promised to set up a scholarship fund for the family with some proceeds from the book. That payback must come from this source is regrettable, but somehow payback seems required. Skloot tells us that people often ask if taking cells without permission is illegal either then (in the 1950s) or now (in 2010). It is not. But even asking the question makes it clear that those people have some sense that payback is required. What kind of payback is something we need to think on.

Fascinating story about how the smallest thing can really impact large change. HeLa cells have had and continue to have an immense impact on the medical/science field. While some might find all the details about descendants of Henrietta and how they have had their ups and downs in life I find it helps put into perspective that she wasn't (isn't) just a cell factory. The family is human and has certainly had is shares of not stellar moments, they didn't hide these for the sake of the book. Skloot's journey to find out just who Henrietta was proved to be beneficial to her loved ones, the journey and discovery was a needed quest to answer their questions and doubts. I can't begin to imagine the emotions felt as relatives read the autopsy report first published elsewhere, not knowing and going through a graphic detailed description of her body being cut open and the details of what was found inside. On the flip side you experience a bit of joy when they get over anger at John Hopkins and start to come to terms with all the discoveries pioneered by this unsung hero. The anger was long lasting for some and it has been a long slow road to open up a discussion on do we have any rights to materials one they are removed from our body.

Can I give it 10 stars? 100? 1000?I've never been so blown away with a book. Ever. I'm going to do everything I can to recommend to every human I know that they read this. It's essential reading. It's a story, so finely researched and written, that, at its very crux, reminds us to be thankful and generous. I admire that the Lacks family has come to see the incredible good that their mother has done for the world; this is a beautiful component of a heartfelt story. I have emerged from the book enlightened in so very many ways. Every person who has ever received healthcare (which is all of us), owes Ms Henrietta Lacks. That's the bottom line.I've donated to the Henrietta Lacks Foundation and may annually. I feel a moral obligation to do so in order to thank one woman who so has been so integral to the progress of medicine -- from which I have directly benefited. I donated with a focus on the unjust and unspeakable irony that her family cannot afford their own health insurance. The foundation is set up to pay for education, medical fees and other issues relating to descendants of Henrietta Lacks, and others who qualify.

I have been meaning to read this book forever, and was aghast to realize it came out in 2010. Whoops! Well, I finally took the time after it was selected for my library's Women's History Month book discussion, and I'm so glad I finally tackled it.What I liked the best was how the author put herself into the narrative, because as the book shows Henrietta's legacy is best served by showing her family, her relatives, and those that survive her.I hope the author will put out an updated edition soon because upon some further research I did find there has been a little head way since 2018, including a board being formed to decide which proposals will be allowed to use Henrietta's immortal cell line, a board that includes two members of her family. Henrietta now further immortalized in the National Portrait Gallery, painted by the amazing Kadir Nelson.

I honestly cannot stop thinking about this book or the Lacks family. I spent all weekend with it because I couldn't put the book down. I am fascinated that not much has changed since 1951 with the legality of abandoned tissue. Sure, now there is informed consent, but what exactly does that mean? I think while the science of the book is great, the heart of the book is the Lacks family. Henrietta's children are more interesting to me than the science. I became interested in the same questions they were asking. What Henrietta's favorite color? How much pain did she suffer? Why did no one tell them what was happening with her tissue? If she saved so many lives through her donation, why couldn't her children get access to health care?Ms. Skloot has written a powerful book and I cannot stop thinking about Henrietta and the children and grandchildren that she left behind. Everyone should read this book.

Good book; minor flaws. Make no mistake, the subject matter is utterly intriguing and the plight of the Lacks family is sympathetic and indeed shocking. Perhaps it was the format of the book that jarred me every time I felt I was really getting into it. I felt that the story got bogged down in certain areas (particularly the legal situations) and it became somewhat repetitive. I enjoyed the back story of Henrietta’s life and the chapters interviewing her family and especially the fascinating science explained in layman’s terms. As a side note I found it off-putting that the author berates other journalists for harassing the Lacks family when she herself did the same thing – example p.228 “For nearly a year after our first conversation, Deborah refused to talk to me.” P.228 “I’d leave messages for Deborah every few days, hoping to convince her that if she talked to me, we could learn about Henrietta together”

This is an important book about an important subject. Not being of a particularly scientific bent I only had a limited understanding of HeLa and the ethical implications. Rebecca Skloot provides an understandable explanation of the the history of HeLa and the person behind the science. The book looks at the struggles of the Lacks family as well as the history of the cells. At times the narrative jumps around a bit and the author's presence in the story can be something of an irritant. However she has done a great service in telling the story of Henrietta Lacks and opening up the ethical issues in an understandable way.The not so casual racism of the medical profession in the 1950s is clearly illustrated as is the experience of the Lacks family in their own struggles with the health services. Parts of the American health system still look too close to Eugenics for my liking and this book highlights areas for ongoing debate

Rebecca Skloot deserves an award for this gem of literature/research. I learned so much about science, ethics, the Hela cell and research procedures during the 90s. In trying to tell Henrietta Lacks' story Skloot walked a thin line between science and explaining cells and the human interest. I found the book really interesting and I didn't find the science information particularly overwhelming. I am actually in awe that the Lacks family had no recognition for basically changing the course of history, it is interesting how time and time again African Americans are erased from the history books, well done Skloot on doing your research and bringing this to light. A MUST READ.

Heart breakingly beautiful. I don't want to give away the ending but to here about the struggle of a family who unknowningly gave so much to the world to receive literally nothing in return is heart breakingly beautiful. Rebecca Skoot did Henrietta's cells justice; as an African American female scientist I could write all day long about the significance this book has to me. I strongly recommend it for everyone but especially those that aspire to work in the science or the medical field. We have to be mindful that everything comes from somewhere. Deeper appreciation for every component of my life the more I think about this book.

This one was on my TBR for a long time, and I'm so glad I finally got to it. An incredibly interesting story about one woman's cells, the interaction between scientific research, consent, and patient involvement (or lack thereof). I found the story of the Lacks family gave the book so much depth, where going into it I had no idea we would spend so much time with them.This was the audio version, which included a little interview with Rebecca Skloot at the end. Very interesting stuff, highly recommended.

I finished this book over vacation. Not exactly a beach novel, but an enjoyable read non the less, about Henrietta Lacks, her cells, her family, and medical ethics. I'm really glad Rebecca Skloot wrote this book and would gladly pick up another book from her in the future. Her reporting is wonderful and accurate, even if it is a bit exhaustive in certain parts.

Wrote from a voice laden with white guilt, it became more of a story about a Black family struggle to survive with a lack of resources instead of the story of the source of the cell which has led to so many modern day advances. It's nearly impossible to deny the importance of the subject matter so I'm still waiting to read the story of HeLa cells.
Everyone should read this!
Fantastic! What fascinating research and the depth of the family involvement in the writing of this book put a human element to these 'cells' used for medical science.
I hate this book. It's all about Rebecca Skloot. Enough said.
Clearly written and informative. A very readable biography of a fascinating woman. Highly recommended!

Henrietta Lacks has probably saved your life. If not yours, then almost certainly that of someone you know.And you don't even know who she is.Or, rather, who she was. The original Henrietta Lacks was a black woman who lived near Baltimore, grew up in poverty, worked hard, and died in 1951, overcome by a cancer that started in her cervix and spread out to take over her whole body. She left behind five children, a husband, and a legacy that would forever change our understanding of biology and medicine.When she first went to Johns Hopkins Medical Center and was diagnosed with cancer, her doctor took a small sample of cells from the tumor and sent it to his colleague, George Gey. Gey had long been in the pursuit of what seemed like and impossible dream: to culture human cells and keep them alive in the lab. By doing so, he hoped to create new ways to test medicine and study human biology without all those pesky patients getting in the way. Unfortunately, his work had thus far been a failure. Human cells, no matter how hard he tried, simply would not survive outside the body for very long. Gey tried all kinds of media and methods, inventing some machines that have become invaluable to cell culture research, but he simply watched culture after culture die in the lab.All of that changed when he got HeLa.The cells from Henrietta Lacks, which were known as "HeLa," not only didn't die - they thrived. They were so robust that Gey and his staff soon had more HeLa cells than they could keep, much less use, so they started sending them off to any researcher who asked. With HeLa, researchers around the world began to make discoveries that would save lives and change the world.But with this ever-growing cell line - which was baked, boiled, frozen, irradiated, cloned, cut up, and sent into space - it was very easy to forget that there was once a woman named Henrietta Lacks, with a family and a legacy of her own.Plenty has been written about HeLa in the last fifty years, and any researcher who works with cells is probably well aware of its existence and importance. But very few people know about Henrietta, and it was this oversight that Rebecca Skloot is trying to correct in this book.She began her quest with a simple question: "Who was Henrietta Lacks?" The fact that she got the right name was surprising enough, actually. HeLa had previously been identified as Henrietta Lakes, Helen Lane, and Helen Larson in various publications. Skloot believed that there was more to the story than just a bunch of immortal cells, and was determined to find Henrietta's surviving relatives and learn more about this woman who had somehow become so important to the world.Skloot wouldn't be the first, however. A writer for Rolling Stone, a con man, and the BBC had all attempted to look into the life of Henrietta before, and found that the surviving Lackses were not only unaware of what their mother had become, but largely unaware of why it was important.The children and grandchildren of Henrietta Lacks had grown up in the Baltimore area, mired in the poverty of being black in the end of the twentieth century. Drug abuse, alcoholism, and a lack of education meant that their lives were full of hardship and struggle, and not likely to get any better. When they found out that Henrietta's cells were not only unique to science but being sold all around the world, this was news that they weren't all prepared to cope with. Some saw it as a religious visitation, others as a massive conspiracy, and still others as just a way to make money off some poor black folk from the city.The center of Skloot's narrative is Deborah, Henrietta's youngest daughter and the one Lacks who seemed most determined to find out what had happened. Deborah wanted so hard to find out what had happened to her mother that it almost killed her. The stress of not knowing - or, even worse, knowing but not understanding - took a heavy toll on her physical and mental health, and she was reluctant to talk to anyone at all about her mother. But it was Deborah that Rebecca had to convince if she was going to write this book, and in order to do that, she had to promise that the book would be about the woman Henrietta was, not just the cells she was famous for.That's probably what makes this book as readable and engaging as it is. While the science is handled well and smoothly, it's not nearly as fascinating or emotionally gripping as the stories that she tells about the Lacks family. She shows us a family that is held together by the strength of their faith in their God and each other, and who are desperately trying to understand their place in the world and how Henrietta came to be what she was.When the original cells were taken from Henrietta, it was done without her consent. She also had no say in what happened to those cells and how they were used, nor did any of her family find out the truth until years later. In an era long before the phrase "informed consent" was even coined, the medical establishment made massive scientific and financial gains, and in the meantime the Lacks were mired in poverty. As several of her children note, Henrietta has changed medicine forever, but her children can't go see a doctor.The struggle to understand must have been enormous. One of the moments that was most surprising and illuminating to me was when Henrietta's son Zakariyya asked Rebecca, "What's a cell?"Just like Rebecca, I had to take a moment to absorb that question, and it put into sharp perspective the vast assumptions that I had made, coming from a well-educated white background. I thought that everyone at least knew what a cell was, but that assumption couldn't have been further from the truth. Deborah and her family are people of minimal formal education who are trying to understand a topic that people study for their entire lives. Their dedication to this quest is so strong, and the struggle is so great that their attempt is nothing less than heroic, to my way of seeing things.The story is still unfinished. HeLa is still out there, making news and causing trouble. The Lacks family is still living in poverty, although the new generation has been able to go to school and are aiming at a brighter future for themselves. And while patients' rights to control what is done with their bodies and their tissues is improving, the law is still on the side of the doctors and hospitals. Medical ethics is a lot better than it was, but the fight is fierce, especially when there's money involved.This book is not just the story of cells or of science. It’s the story of a woman and her family, and how sometimes people get lost in the inexorable movement of scientific progress. Some parts are infuriating, some are heartbreaking, but the book is an illumination into what is sometimes sacrificed in pursuit of a better world.-----"When I saw those toenails, I nearly fainted. I thought, Oh jeez, she's a real person. I started imagining her sitting in her bathroom painting those toenails, and it hit me for the first time that those cells we'd been working with all this time and sending all over the world, they came from a live woman. I'd never thought of it that way."- Mary Kubicek, assistant to George Gey

Ugh... I'll tell you what - if it wasn't 2 weeks from the end of the year, and if I wasn't currently 12 books behind on my already-reduced yearly goal, I wouldn't actually be reviewing this book right now. I'd be sitting on it and waiting to re-read it, because I feel like it's a book that needs the proper kind of read, and... I just didn't really give it that. To be clear, I finished it, and really loved it, but... Basically I have been listening to this book in like 4 minute spurts for like 8 months. Never so officially that I even added it to my Currently Reading shelf. (And it kinda makes me a little neurotic, to be honest.) This book has been with me through two cars now, three if we count the rental while my poor car was being evaluated and eventually written off as a total loss. We've been through SEASONS together. And the whole time, I've been just fascinated and really enthralled with the story of these cells and this woman and her family, and the way that science and even ethics have changed because of them. It's a fantastic and heart-wrenching story, and one I absolutely will be revisiting more attentively at some point. No, attentive isn't really the right word, because as I listened, even in the few minutes I might be in the car, I was that. Maybe, consistently? Continuously? Something like that. Anyway, this is non-fiction, but it reads and feels like a fictionalized story. The 'plot' is incredible, the 'characters' are real and flawed and human, and the 'storytelling' is structured in such a way that the reader learns what the family learns essentially as they learn it. Knowing that these are real people, who actually LIVED this, just makes the story all the more powerful and important. I loved this book. Cannot recommend it highly enough.

Random thoughts and questions after reading this book: 1. As an acquaintance said of the book, "The author was considerably less interesting to me than she was to herself." Amen. 2. I am OK with a few praise blurbs from other authors in a book, and I guess the (exhaustive and exhausting three pages) listing of every prize or award Skloot won since her third grade spelling bee was inevitable, but to have to page through no fewer than 58 MORE quotes about how earth-shatteringly fabulous this book is....ARE YOU F***ING KIDDING ME? And a couple of these praise blurbs are only one or two words. That's what I call questionable use of a scalpel. It's possible to pull one positive sounding word from even the worst review. If she were male, I'd think she was compensating for a less-than-impressive body part. I have a theory that the number of praise blurbs and review quotes appearing in the front of a book is inversely proportional to the quality of the writing inside the book. This glut did nothing to convince me my theory is wrong. (Do authors really believe readers aren't well aware that many of those PR quotes are solicited (or wrangled, begged, and bought) or that authors usually write their own swaggering bios?) 3. Skloot emphasizes that the Lacks family was skittish about talking to strangers because of numerous bad experiences with reporters, con men, etc, but she hounded them longer and harder than anyone. She comes off like some wacko stalker -- calling several times daily, showing up at people's houses, working her way toward the family by trying to chum up to distant cousins or townsfolk, not respecting "no" as an answer. Considering some of the places she was inserting herself, she's lucky not to have ended up on the business end of a shotgun. (I grew up in an area very much like Halifax County, VA -- and not that far from it -- and it was clear to me while reading about her interactions with folks in Clover that Skloot has all the cultural insight of a housefly.) 4. Once Skloot wears the family down to get access to Deborah Lacks, she suddenly becomes Deborah's BFF. And yet, in spite of ALL those professed years of visits and phone calls and travels together where they giggled and read and...hell, IDK, painted each other nails...the family (supposedly) didn't have Skloot's phone number in order to tell her Deborah died? That seems weird. Even if they really had lost the number, there's this little thing called directory assistance. That is, if they really wanted to contact her. Methinks she wasn't as BFF as she wants us to think. Also? She should have shared author credit with Deborah if she wanted to be as "fair" as she claims.5. Skloot is President of the Henrietta Lacks Foundation, which she claims she set up prior to writing the book in order to provide educational care for the Lacks descendants. Is Skloot compensated financially in that role? If so, how much does she make from it? Good luck finding financial disclosures about this tax-exempt org. Call me cynical, but the whole "an undisclosed amount of some proceeds from the book I wrote go toward the tax-exempt foundation I happen to be head of" makes me think "riiiight...PR stunt." 6. The book is repetitive and organizationally all over the place, but there are basically two parts. The part about the HeLa cells, how they were acquired, grown, distributed, used, and the contamination problems with them, which is interesting and approachable. The part depicting the Lacks family and their long history of abuse, drugs, arrests, poverty, STDs, teen pregnancies, etc. felt gratuitous and exploitative. Skloot tries to paint herself as someone who "gets it and will fix it" and yet it's pretty obvious by her self-congratulatory comments that this really is all about Skloot: her interests, her curiosity, her book, her royalties. 7. I would have liked a clear explanation of why using cancerous cells to develop medications and treatments doesn't compromise the effect of those products. The issue was broached, then brushed aside. 8. I don't think anyone would argue that it's a sad irony that Henrietta Lacks' family can't afford medical care while Henrietta's cancer cells have made the career of many researchers and profited many corporations. Yes, that's tragic and seems like some kind of cruel joke of the universe; however, there's not a direct cause-and-effect relationship here. There are many, many poor people who manage to stay out of jail, stay in school, not abuse or molest anyone, and not do drugs. Deborah Lacks seemed to be the only one interested in more than a handout or someone to write them a check. If the Lacks boys want to blame someone for their situation, maybe they should have looked in mirrors. And maybe they should have asked their father why he couldn't keep his pants zipped or at least wear a condom rather than repeatedly infect their mother with every STD under the sun. The truly sad irony is that David Lacks lived to a ripe old age in spite of inflicting the effects of STDs on his entire brood. Now, that seems unjust.9. The hard part of history is that you have to put events in the context of their times. In 1951, even had Henrietta Lacks been a white, middle-class, educated woman, it is very likely that her cells still would have been taken without consent or compensation. Today it is easy to say the cells should not have been used without permission, but in 1951 that was not uncommon practice. What surprised me was to learn that, once removed from the host body, our cells can still be used without explicit consent. 10. Perhaps the most important part of the book is about current ethical questions surrounding cell collection and use. This is where the real meat is. Why is that stuck in the very back of the book?Summary: An important story, but the author's tendency to sensationalize and cast herself in the starring role as some great white savior marching in to educate and help those poor, simple, messed-up, backward black folks was just too much to stomach. I'd like to see this story told by someone who doesn't consider him or her self the hero.

What I wanted to talk about and not talk about too much is The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks, probably the most important book that I have read in the last twenty years. It moved me, terrified me, intrigued me, and thoroughly exhausted every fiber of my being, however, and in spite of all of that, I strongly believe this is a book that every informed person in the Western world should read. I had to pace myself and not follow the desire of reading late into the night; the one time I did, I was not able to sleep well for a few days. This is a book that every writer in the world would probably wish to have written not only because of its immense success but because of its humanity, the lack of sensationalism, and the important and fascinating nature of the topics it covers. The writing is simple enough to make complicated real-life stories and real-life science relatively easy to understand; no purple prose, the power of the content needs no other adornment than a meticulous and well-researched treatment. A fantastic and thought-provoking read. If you have been thinking about giving it a try, brace yourself and go for it, it is totally worth it. You might also want to check out the webpage of the Henrietta Lacks foundation: http://henriettalacksfoundation.org.

I'm normally not a non-fiction fan but The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks reads like historical fiction. The story of Henrietta is vivid and comes to life on the page. Not only is it a story about a family and the losses they are dealing with. It is a story of racial and ethical issues in medicine and all that is done for "science." I highly recommend this book and think it would be a great pick for book clubs. There's so much to discuss!

By some freak medical accident, the cancer cells of Henrietta Lacks lived and replicated outside of her body long after her death, revolutionizing the science of cell culture and leading to hundreds if not thousands of scientific advances in medicine. And that is the least interesting part of this story.What is interesting about The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks is the combination of racism, poverty, and lack of patients' rights that led to this medical marvel, and the painful aftermath of Henrietta's death. Because the author rightly picked up on the fact that you can't tell the story of the HeLa cells without telling the story of Henrietta Lacks and her descendants. You can't separate the awful legacy of racism and poverty from the medical experimentation that made the HeLa cells possible. And you can't separate the real, tragic lives of Henrietta's family from the miraculous scientific advances to which the HeLa cells contributed.As someone who is firmly pro-choice, I found the legal aspect of the book deeply disturbing. Henrietta's cells were taken without her knowledge or consent. They might have died, in which case they would have been discarded like hundreds of cell samples before them. But they weren't: Henrietta's cells lived and multiplied, a genuine medical break-through. And yet she still wasn't informed. Henrietta Lacks wasted away in a hospital bed, dying of cervical cancer while doctors and scientists at Johns Hopkins made scientific history using her biological tissue. And she never knew anything about it.And I just... don't understand how that ever could have been legal. Not the use of the tissue, but the lack of consent. Mandatory organ donation is not legal, and using someone's body without their consent is not legal. So how was it ever ok for doctors to remove cells for experiments without getting the consent of the owner of those cells? That... is horrifying.I find it a little easier to understand the justification for using tissues removed consensually, without informing the tissue donor of their use. I get that restricting the use of donated tissues could put up a roadblock for medical science and we all might therefore miss out on medical advances. But to take samples without even asking? To keep tissue on file without consent? Murky ethical waters, man. But of course, Henrietta Lacks was a poor black woman. She was raised on a tobacco farm, married her first cousin, dropped out of elementary school, and had contracted a number of STIs from her husband. So who the hell cares what happens to her or what she thinks, amirite? The history of medical experimentation on impoverished black people was disgusting and shameful. And even now, based on the interviews Skloot conducted for this book, there are doctors who just. don't. care.Which is why the person of Henrietta Lacks can't be separated from the story of her cells. It's important that the author formed a personal relationship with Henrietta's daughter Deborah, because Deborah is a real person, deeply and negatively affected by what happened to her mother. This poor woman lived her life afflicted by all the ills of poverty, and was uniquely vulnerable to the stress and anxiety of knowing how her mother was violated and taken advantage of. And yet even when Deborah was paranoid and freaking out in a way that could even be called "crazy," I felt nothing but admiration and compassion for her. Once she found out the truth of the HeLa cells, she fought constantly to educate herself, to uncover the truth, and to honor her mother, her family, and her history. And she did it all without the benefit of a high school education. This is an incoherent review, which is regretful, because there's a lot of complicated shit going on in this book. It inspired me to think critically about the cost of scientific and medical advancement. It inspired me to evaluate the power differential between the privileged educated and the impoverished uneducated. And on top of that, it's just a damn good story.

Amazing story of an African-American woman who unknowingly provided cells for most of the medical research done around the world beginning in 1952. The Lacks family never benefitted from what became a billion dollar industry that cultured Henrietta's cancer cells for use in tests and experiments. In fact, they were economically deprived and could not even afford medical care. Author Rebecca Skloot investigates how this came about, tracking down the Lacks family members and learning how the family survived (it's a heart wrenching story) and informing them about Henrietta's importance. Chapters on the family alternate with the story with how Henrietta's cells were taken and how their culturing became such big business and so scientifically important. And all the chapters are page turners. The only place the book slows down is at the very end where there is discussion and analysis of how to deal with human tissue. Who does it belong to? Does a patient have to give consent for the tissue, blood, etc. to be used (think about organs removed during surgery, or moles taken off)? In 1952 no one even thought about those things. Now we're grappling with patenting DNA. There are no easy answers. I felt kind of sad and let down at the end of the book because the Lacks family (or what was left of it--many had passed away) was in such poor circumstances, until I found the page about the Henrietta Lacks Foundation, set up by Rebecca Skloot before the book was published. Some of the proceeds from the book go to the foundation. I went to the website HenriettaLacksFoundation.org where I found that several members of the Lacks family had been given assistance for medical and dental problems and others had received assistance in paying for their education. Assistance is available to any individual or their family member whose life has been impacted by medical research. This is not limited to the Lacks family; anyone who has had their tissue, blood, or genetic material used for medical research and received no compensation is eligible to apply for a grant.I urge you you to read this book to know Henrietta Lacks' story, to know the hard life of African Americans in the United States, to know how poor education and economic hardship combined with the medical practices of the 1950s to leave the family ignorant and bewildered about what happened to their family member, and to see how that situation created damaging fear and denial. You will also learn how science progressed so quickly that it ran ahead of rules and ethical practices and how racism was so ingrained in society that no one even thought about it when medical experiments were done on African Americans (the Tuskegee syphilis study looms large here). And you will be introduced to ethical dilemmas about balancing individual patient rights with the need to do medical research that benefits everyone (and there have been some huge benefits for all of us). Your brain will get a workout, your heart will be broken, you will be angry, sad, frustrated and, I hope, determined to do something. A donation to the Henrietta Lacks Foundation would be a good place to start.

My thoughts about this book are a bit scattered, and perhaps my situation in the midst of what is starting to shape up as a chronic health problem didn't put me in the best frame of mind for reading it. I truly expected to love it, but I don't think I did. First, I almost always dislike it when the author of a non-memoir, non-fiction work becomes a main character in the story and that's what you saw here. I felt for the Lacks family, and the impact of the poverty and lack of education on the generations of the family followed here, but I also felt that Skloot might have done some members of the family a disservice by publishing this warts-and-all account of their lives, especially since their difficulties continue into present-day. Don't get me wrong - I don't doubt that Skloot had/has real affection for the Lackses, but they are portrayed as a family who hasn't risen above, and, in many cases, just the opposite. And she seems to place at least a portion for the blame for that at the feet of....well, who, exactly? Johns Hopkins? The medical research machine? For-profit biological corporations? A racist society? Or all of the above? However, there's no clear connection drawn.In addition, Skloot takes pains to separate herself from all the other journalists who have come to the Lacks story before her....SHE certainly had no intention of using this family in any way, right? Except that she's become a famous, award-winning author from this book, and while her brief statement at the end of the book indicating that she's set up a foundation for the family, indicating that "some profits" will be donated to it, there's no clear statement of exactly how much, and for what purposes, precisely (and I realize that her lawyers wouldn't let her be more specific, but still...) In distinguishing her own motives from other authors, she even chastises Michael Gold, but it seems clear that she used his work extensively as a reference source, a separation that strikes me as disingenuous at best. Perhaps my other difficulty with the book was the tone of an overall indictment of the medical research community. Cell research was in its infancy in the early 1950s. Henrietta's cells were a true miracle, but not one that could have been anticipated - I can only imagine that scientists all over the world took thousands of such liberties, but it would be difficult to argue that they didn't serve the greater good, and, as much as I feel for the Lacks family, there is simply no way to rectify that error now, so it was often frustrating to read about the Lackses palpable anger with no direction.It's not that I hated the book, I just didn't love it. Henrietta Lacks lived a brief, difficult life and died in horrendous circumstances that were borne of both biology and society. She lives on through what her wondrous cells have given the world, and even though I wasn't crazy about the book, I'm glad that she, and her family, are receiving their due.

Generally, I prefer fiction to non-fiction. Perhaps it's my way of rebelling against all the twits who say they don't read fiction because you can't learn anything from it. I don't know. However, I read a review of this book in The New York Times, and it was glowing, to say the least. They managed to convey both the skill of the writing and the pull of the story, and I knew I had to check out the book, so check it out I did, quite literally. I put my name on a waiting list at the library, a waiting list which was hundreds of people long, and I waited.Last Tuesday, I was finally able to get the book. As I've noted elsewhere, recently, I've been doing more knitting than reading. I haven't even finished reading a book since the beginning of the year, something very uncommon for me. I was excited, then, to have a book with a time limit. I had two weeks and only two weeks to finish before the book had to go back to the library and off to the next person on the waiting list. Well, since I'm writing this on Sunday and since I finished the book on Saturday, you can see that I didn't need the two weeks after all.Talk about a page-turner! I couldn't put it down. I was even reading in class, and I'm the teacher. Whenever I assigned my students something to read, they'd read their thing, and I'd read this book. When they had to write, they'd write, and I'd read this book. Aside from class, I read on the bus rides to and from the city. I didn't read much at home. Still, though, I managed to get through it pretty quickly.Part of what made it such a page-turner were the characters and the ethical issues the book brought up. The Lacks family is at the same time so foreign to my experience but also so utterly human and understandable. I couldn't help wondering how different their lives would have been had they known about their mother's cells and had they seen some of the profit that so many others have as a result of those cells. The ethical issues go beyond money and fair compensation, though. The issue of race and the racial history of the US also play a big role. I was absolutely tickled to think about how many virulent racists might have HeLa cells or medicines made from them floating around in their bodies. According to the one drop rule, we might all be black now. However, I also cried thinking that at the same time MLK, Jr. and others were fighting for civil rights, a black woman was helping to save so many lives from polio and getting no credit at all for it. The world truly is a complicated and messy place, and this book helps to bring to light some of that complication and mess and at the same time gives us faith in writers who want justice for their subjects and the people who somehow muddle through even when there is none.

A tough time rating this book... the questions raised by this book and the story that's in it - a 5 all the way, so I'll have to explain. I can see why there are great reviews - the questions raised in this book are timely and poignant and end in heated, gonna-slap-you-silly debates. But the book doesn't live up to that fever. I had a few jaw-dropping moments and "Oh &*&*, can they really do that?" questions. But I pretty much had that ephiphany in the first 100 pages and then the rest was sort of an anti-climactic ride. It's like I stood in line for 2 hours, anxious and excited to ride the best, most stomach-turning roller coaster in the park, arrive at the front of the line and realized with great dismay - I was in the line for the carousel! Boring. Eh. SOOOO disappointed by the hype. I felt bad for the Lacks family, but not as bad as maybe I SHOULD have. I couldn't help but be torn - if all of that GOOD came from the medical discoveries, perhaps there SHOULDN'T be a dime made off it, much like organ donation, but then when I read about the profits of companies off of HeLa cells for any jo-shmo stupid research? Yeah, I felt a tug toward the Lacks family. By page 230 though, I really was completely bored. I was bored with cells. Bored by the long list of doctors. Bored. And I'm ashamed to admit this, but I was sort of bored with the Lack's story; this sort of ignorance was actually making me mad. I felt like Deborah was the one making the effort and WANTING to learn and being tormented and that the others, who admittedly didn't really remember their mother, sort of jumped on the bandwagon. I felt Deborah was the only one truly tormented by the HeLa debacle and had an intrinsic need to know about her mother. I felt others in the family were victims of abuse and a terrible upbringing and lack of education, yes, but Deborah I thought was the one really affected by the HeLa mess. I think for years, people asked questions and noone really thought much about it until (tada)... the HeLa cells were being sold and whoa - shouldn't the family make a profit? THEN many family members cared. That kind of irked me thinking some in the family didn't really have the best of intentions, but it's hard to judge and I don't want to do that; I don't really know these people, but that's my honest reaction to the book. I definitely love social injustice stories, but that was in that first 100 pages and got me fired up, ready to care, but then... I didn't feel that was really the WHOLE story. Ah what can I say? It was just ok for me.

How would you feel if your doctor took a sample of your tissue without your consent and then used it to further his own research studies and then shared that tissue with laboratories and medical research centers around the world for a profit? After your death, what would happen if your family discovered that your cells had been used in medical research against the family's wishes for years, but that those cells had also been used to make some of the most important innovations that modern science has ever known? This is what happened to an African American woman named Henrietta Lacks in 1951. Henrietta was diagnosed with an aggressive form of cancer that eventually led to her death. Her doctors at Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore discovered that Henrietta's cells were immortal, meaning that they could be grown in a lab without dying after a few cell divisions. Samples of Henrietta's cancerous tissue were taken without her knowledge or consent during her treatments and then again after her death. Henrietta's cells were used to conduct many experiments from developing a cure for polio and studying the effects of radiation and other toxic substances on the human body to gene mapping as well as cancer and AIDS research. Her cells represented a boon to medical research.In the meantime, Henrietta's family had been kept in the dark. They lived in poverty and poor health, often without health insurance, and they only found out about her contribution to science years later. Journalist Rebecca Skloot does an excellent job of gathering what little information there is on Henrietta's life and telling her remarkable story and the aftermath of her death. It's unusual for a journalist to get so close to the subjects she is writing about, but Rebecca's close relationship with the family only made me feel more indignant about how they were treated. The end of the novel, in particular, was a real eye-opener for me. I had spent so much time feeling angry about what had happened to the Lacks' that I never stopped to consider what would've happened if Henrietta's cells hadn't been used. This isn't a story about Henrietta Lacks, although she is certainly the most important figure in this novel. It's about her children, her friends, and the debate over whether or not human tissue should be used with or without a patient's consent and what that means for the future of medical science.

Author Rebecca Skloot first heard about HeLa cells in an introduction to biology class she took at a community college as a makeup for a failed high school class. The lecture about HeLa cells and Henrietta Lacks ended with, "She was a black woman." That statement launched the author's interest in biology and piqued her curiosity into the life of Henrietta Lacks. By the time she earned a degree in biology, Skloot had decided to write a book about the woman whose cells survived long after her death.I almost didn't read this book. It was at first a need to read rather than a desire to read. Then my daughter (an Ob/Gyn) told me it was a must read, and my own Gyno said I must read. I asked my doc if a layperson would be able to understand all the biological/medical language and she assured me the book is historical and biographical as well. I was convinced to start reading. It didn't take long before I was reading into the night about the life of Henrietta Lacks.The author wisely alternates between chapters about Henrietta's genealogy, life, treatment, death; and the clinical studies, distribution of the cells grown from the biopsy taken from Henrietta's cervical cancer. The author chronicles her knowledge of unethical experimentation on human patients ranging from Nazi experiments on concentration camp inmates to the Tuskegee syphilis experiment. The outrage recorded during the Nuremberg trials never resulted in changes in medical practice or ethics, so that no requirement for informed consent was written into law.Ms. Skloot traces Henrietta's family back to a slave plantation in Virginia, through the Jim Crow era when there was little access to medical treatment for poor blacks. Henrietta was part of the Great Migration, moving to Baltimore where Johns Hopkins Hospital provided medical treatment for blacks often in exchange for uninformed participation in clinical studies.It became painful to read of Henrietta's lack of access to a peaceful and pain-free transition though a horrendously painful death, especially when juxtaposed against the multi-million dollar industry which grew out of the cancerous cells taken from her.Ms Skloot spent years tracing Henrietta's children, who were babies at the time of her death in 1951. As Skloot learns about the life of Henrietta, her children have a glimpse into the mother they never knew as well.This is a true story you must read. I give it five stars.

The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks is a paradox of a novel; it somehow simultaneously feels too padded and too cramped. In a scant three hundred pages it attempts to be a historical novel about the creation and importance of cell cultures, an even-handed treatment of ideas regarding the often shady and pockmarked intersection of science and ethics, and an inspirational family chronicle of the Lacks clan in the fifty years since Henrietta's death. And to be honest the first section of the novel dealing directly with Henrietta's life and death are just about able to pull it off. Unfortunately at some point it's obvious Skloot got overwhelmed and fell back on the easiest subject to write about: yourself. The second half of Henrietta Lacks is a scattershot mess, largely taken up by Skloot's personal odyssey to infiltrate the Lacks clan and her personal relationship with Deborah Lacks, the family's de facto matriarch. This is plagued with innumerable setbacks, tragedies, family members reversing their opinion of her, etc, and I couldn't help but feel that I was reading some bizarre "making of" book appended to the main story. Don't tell me about how difficult it was for you to make this book, about the struggles and hardships you faced - tell me more about Henrietta, more about the HeLa strain and it's history and importance to science. There's an incredibly interesting story about cross-contamination of the HeLa line causing a giant revamp to medical science (not to mention hundreds of millions of dollars in losses) in the 1980's that's glossed over in a few pages so I can hear more about Skloot's adventures living out of hotel rooms in Southern Virginia. Also, It just feels wrong to me somehow that she "preserved" the diction of Henrietta's family in order to make them sound like infantile morons, and I especially felt Skloot's whole "gee golly I sure am an athiest but the faith of this poor black family who've been treated like dirt for 50 years is making me reconsider my faith in Jesus" schtick near the end to be almost disgustingly patronizing. Henrietta Lacks' story is incredibly interesting to medical science, bioethics and American history - but this book does a terrible job of showing it.

This is an interesting, if light, work of nonfiction. Henrietta Lacks was a poor black woman who went to the charity ward of Johns Hopkins in 1951 with cervical cancer. Cells were taken from her body without her knowledge, and unlike other cells collected up to that point, they kept reproducing.... endlessly. Mrs. Lacks died a few months afterwards, but her cells became standard lab material over the world, used in the development of everything from the polio vaccine to the atomic bomb. Her family found out two decades later, and didn’t see a dime of the profits.I enjoyed this book, reading almost all of it in one day. Skloot is a skilled storyteller, with an accessible, engaging journalistic style. The early section dealing with Henrietta Lacks’s life is probably the best. It's a kind of story that isn't usually told, and Skloot does a good job of relating the information she was able to gather, without speculating on the parts we can't know. A few chapters discuss the science, though mostly on a surface level; readers with little interest or background in science should not be scared away, as these chapters are brief and accessible. The section dealing with the history of medical experimentation on unconsenting African-Americans is especially memorable.However, a large portion of the book, particularly in the second half, deals with the author’s journey in researching the book and gaining the trust of the Lacks family, and focuses on her friendship with Henrietta’s daughter, Deborah. This story is well-told, and I do think the Lacks family needed to be part of this book; their discovery of their mother’s cells had an enormous impact on their lives, and the irony of their inability to afford health care would be impossible to miss even if the book didn’t point it out. But devoting so much of the book to the author’s researching it does make it seem, in the final analysis, rather light. Compared to most nonfiction, it’s less informative and a quicker read; this accessibility no doubt contributed to its bestseller status, but much as I enjoyed it, I didn't learn nearly as much as I'd expected. At least the Lacks family is finally benefiting from their ordeal.

An amazing book full of important scientific, legal, ethical, family, and medical industry information while also a very well told story of a woman and her family. Ms. Skloot is a very good writer, told an honest story and told it well. Very moving and very important in so many ways. The writing keeps you drawn in and interested in an amazing way.

It's not my normal fare, this book. I've been most reluctant to delve into biology beyond the basics taught at high school, and I didn't think I would enjoy this book. I did and then I didn't, but the science was my favorite part. When the book focuses on HeLa, or Henrietta herself (which is a really tiny portion of the book, but it still stands out), or the ethics of the scientific community, it's at its strongest. I was fully engaged in the book when these were being discussed, especially since I'm kind of paranoid about hospitals and doctors in general. But focus is the problem here. Midway through, Skloot runs out of things to say about HeLa and science and ethics. This could be because the times were different, and the Lacks family didn't actually make a concerted effort to get their concerns redressed. In any case, there's nothing left to say on those fronts, and Skloot turns the book into a human interest story focussing on the HeLa offspring. But, she doesn't do a good job there. When I came to the portion where Deborah finally figures out that it's her mother's cancer cells that were multiplying and not her normal cells by a friendly oncologist, I didn't want to read anymore. Why could this information not have come from Skloot, who went out of her way to write several times that no one was giving the Lacks family any information? It's such a tiny piece that would have helped Deborah, and it bothered me a lot. There was too much of Skloot in the book, and not enough anyone else. I don't know - I like my non-fiction with the author at a distance unless it's an autobiography or an opinion piece. This was neither. The book really should have ended at around 200 pages.The book did make me think. I give blood, and I blindly sign my consent form. This is not because I'm not educated, or I'm lazy. I just lack the imagination. I've no idea what can happen. This book gives the answers. I just don't know if I like them.

As a medic just starting a new position in research I felt now was the right time to read this book which had been on my to-read list for years. The books tells the true story of Henrietta Lacks, a poor African-American lady in the 1950s who developed an aggressive form of cervical cancer. Unbeknown to her, cells were taken from her during investigation and treatment which become the 1st cells to survive and grow in cell culture. They went on to become the almost ubiquitous cell line HeLa which has been used in thousands of research projects since. Henrietta died leaving a devastated young family to grow up with much suffering along the way. This book tells their story as well as what little is known about Henrietta and provides a fascinating look into their difficult lives and is an interesting piece of social commentary. The family found out about the HeLa cells many years on and due to a lack of understanding were understandable very upset at the thought of their mothers cells being out there, still growing. The main problem, to me, was the total lack of explanation to the family or no attempt to seek consent. Personally, I don't think there was any ethical problem with using the cells but the lack of empathy towards the family is where the problems arose. The book also discusses the history of cell culture and delves into the development of research ethics as a concept. The values we base trials and research on have evolved from the issues discussed in this book and this is hugely important to maintaining trust with the public and medical researchers so drugs and treatments can continue to be developed. This book makes you think. It makes you want to discuss medical ethics. It makes me eternally grateful to the researchers, who even if they didn't go about things as we would now, worked tirelessly to develop cell culture which is a foundation of so much medical knowledge. Lastly, it makes me want to thank Henrietta Lacks

The history of medicine has a real sleazy side to it, and if you have any doubts about that, this book will put them to rest. It's the story of a black woman whose cancer was so virulent, it actually outlived her. Her cells have been cultured, reproduced, sold, and become the basis of some of the most important breakthroughs in modern medicine, but the cells were taken from her without her knowledge or consent. Her family only discovered it decades later. The book raises all kinds of sticky yet relevant questions about medical ethics and race, showing both the good and the bad of medical science.A few weeks ago, I reviewed Polio: An American Story here on Goodreads, saying that because of its focus on the human side of the search for the polio vaccine, the book read like a novel. That's even more true for this book since the author focuses so particularly on Henrietta's family and even on her own research process in tracking them down. So if my Polio review convinced you to read that book, I strongly urge you to read this as a follow-up. Henrietta's cells were central to the discovery of the polio vaccine, yet like with everything else connected with her, her story was completely unknown until this book. And the converse is also true: if you've read this book yet haven't read Polio: An American Story, I recommend it as a follow-up. I know it didn't mention Henrietta Lacks, and I don't think it even mentioned HeLa cells, but once you've read one book, you've got enough of a background to appreciate the other.

I'm always stunned when I learn about a piece of history that seems much more like fiction. The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks by Rebecca Skloot is just such a case.
