(Update as of August 2013 at bottom.)Excellent, but not really a science book. Which is only of interest to me because it was the book-of-the-month for a one science café's reading group I sometimes attend, and the author read and answered questions at another science café I go to.Of course, science forms a large part of the background story. The changing paradigm of scientific ethics, actually, is central to how HeLa became famous and, now, infamous.But the twin narratives that really drive this book aren't scientific stories. One was the tale of how the HeLa cells got into the research domain in the first place, and how it has been used since then — and how a lack of understanding of the virulence of the cell line has caused no small number of problems.The other narrative was the personal story of how the author slowly won over the survivors of Lacks' family. Synergistically, the research Skloot had to do for the first was exactly what let her break through the barrier of suspicion and mistrust: the Lacks family didn't have the knowledge, skill or contacts to do the research that Skloot did, and her persistence in transparently sharing her findings with the family slowly brought them around.Unfortunately, I was reading this primarily as a science book, and in that context it only earns three stars: "liked it". Although this is non-fiction, I've also tagged it as "chick-lit" because the larger story is really a melodramatic one that I suspect really appeals to the Oprah crowd. So, if you enjoyed Steel Magnolias but also enjoy the domain of science non-fiction, this might be a sweet read.      •       •       •       •       •       •       •Update, summer 2013—The New York Times reports that the family of Henrietta Lacks is now formally involved in the research into their ancestor's cell line, which is satisfactory at least due to the privacy considerations about their own genetics, as well as ameliorating the unsettling sense of injustice at their complete disassociation from the research. The case served as an extreme example in the debate over research and medical use of tissue harvested for other purposes.
Jeri Lacks Whye, center, one of Henrietta Lacks’s grandchildren, with her own daughters, Jabrea, left, and Aiyana Rogers.Photo by Monica Lopossay for The New York Times­

The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks was on pretty much every Top Ten Books of 2010 list. It is the story of Henrietta Lacks, a black woman in the fifties who had cervical cancer. A doctor at Johns Hopkins took her cells without asking, and those cells, dubbed HeLa, never died. And they single-handedly (single-cellularly?) changed the face of science and medicine as we know it. This is not hyperbole, and Skloot makes it clear through the many, many examples of research in which HeLa cells were instrumental. Vaccines, new therapies, new understanding of cancer itself, new insights into DNA, and so on. Without these cells—which I have worked with myself—I cannot imagine where we would be today.While Skloot makes sure we understand the importance of the cells, her focus is on Henrietta Lacks, the woman from whom those cells were taken. Yes, taken. These cells were taken from her, they were grown, they were sold, and she and her family received nothing. It is one hell of an irony that Henrietta's cells revolutionized modern medicine, but her children can't afford health insurance. But this is not an angry, condemning book. Skloot—a science writer who explains the science and scientific discoveries with ease—is more interested in the human element. Who was Henrietta? Where did she grow up? Who knew her? What do her children know about her? Well, it took them a couple decades, but they did find out that the cells of their mother were still floating around all over the world, and they weren't too pleased.The book is divided into three sections: Birth, which mainly concerns the life of Henrietta Lacks; Death, which mainly concerns the scientific and medical revolution her cells caused; and Immortality, which continues that thread and introduces bioethics into the mix but mainly focuses on Skloot's interactions with the Lacks family as she does research for the book. To my surprise, despite my desire to know more about Henrietta—the reason I read the book—and my fascination with all the science, my favorite part of the book, the part when I was most engaged, was the last hundred pages, as Skloot forms a relationship with Deborah Lacks, Henrietta's daughter, and, together, they find out what they can about her mother. Perhaps because this is when Skloot is telling a very personal story, it feels so much more real and intimate. Skloot has a real knack for storytelling, however, and she's given very good material by, you know, the facts. So much of what she's describing is probably public knowledge but to someone who's unfamiliar with all the details, man, are you in for some fucking surprises.It's a book that touches on faith, science, racism, bioethics, life, death, medicine, family, and many other things in an incredibly readable, well-researched fashion. It's a story that needed to be told, and it's a marvelous accomplishment.

In general, I prefer fiction to nonfiction. That isn’t a knock on nonfiction at all – I prefer reading as a means of escape, and often nonfiction doesn’t offer enough of a break from reality for me, what with it being based on reality and all. Plus, I find a lot of nonfiction to be rather dry. Such it is. Not all, but a good chunk of it.The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks is not at all dry. It was fascinating and I couldn’t put it down. Ripped right through the thing, hardly waiting to see what happened next. Basically, Rebecca Skloot took a biology class at a community college. In the midst of learning about cells, her professor mentioned that the HeLa line of immortal cells, which have been used for countless bits of life-saving research, came from a woman named Henrietta Lacks. Skloot got curious, and spent ten years of her life learning about Henrietta’s life, and the ongoing life of the HeLa cells.The book alternates between Henrietta’s life – growing up on a tobacco plantation, marriage, kids, and ultimately her cancer, the story of HeLa – how the cells were harvested, how they grew, and where they went and what they did for science, and Skloot’s story of tracking down and meeting Henrietta’s family. Henrietta never knew that any of her cancer cells were taken, and never gave permission for them to be taken. Her family learned of it years later, long after the HeLa line had been passed scientist-to-scientist around the world and had been mass-produced in labs for huge profits. None of that matters, of course. Doctors don’t need permission, don’t need to tell patients, and patients (and their families) retain no ownership in such cells.All three stories are engaging and woven together in a way that makes sense. Skloot explains much of the science without dumbing it down or talking over readers’ heads. That is a true gift.My only gripe was that Skloot spent too much time patting herself on the back. Other white folks tried to talk to the Lacks family but she got through because she really had their best interests. The Lackses were very skeptical but she was so awesome that they warmed up to her and love her now. Nobody ever explained just what the cells did to the Lackses but Rebecca showed up and she told them all the things and made it all better because she is JUST THAT GOOD. Eyeroll. But I guess that’s part of what happens when you’re telling a story that you’ve invested 10 years of your life in, and your involvement is part of the story. Can’t be too annoyed.Highly recommend this one. It was fantastic.

WARNING: Reading this book may incite anger in the reader regarding racism, medical ethics and poverty.HeLa cells were first cultured in 1951. Nearly 60 years later The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks debuted and became a best seller. In between, there was a complex Lacks family history, a fascination with chicken heart immortality, and some very real groundbreaking science. Henrietta Lacks died of cancer in 1951, shortly after the tissue was removed from her body without her knowledge or permission and neither she nor her family benefited financially from the discoveries made possible by her cells. This fascinating book covers it all: the historic, the oddity, the racism and the science. For Rebecca Skloot the book is the culmination of a dream since she was a teenager about uncovering the story of the HeLa cells, both the star and the workhorse of cellular biology and laboratory experimentation. Just so there will be no confusion, the author begins with the assertion “This is a work of nonfiction. No names have been changed, no characters invented, no events fabricated.“ That is not to say that the story is easy to believe. But this is a well written, accessible and compelling book that is filled with lessons learned and unlearned.Much to be said about this book. And you will be happy to know that 9009 reviewers have collectively said all of it more than several times! So I will not add to it! I will gladly join the four star people and say that I am glad that my daughter in law Susan sent me a copy of this book. Would that the racism and poverty that are illuminated here could be eliminated from the world. It makes me angry that our system heaps so much adversity on so many people. HeLa cells have not been the panacea for the ills of society and it is ironic that the family of a woman who is the source of so much good has suffered so much.

In The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks, Rebecca Skloot has written an intelligent, moving nonfiction narrative that tells the story of the Lacks family and the HeLa cells.Henrietta Lacks (1920-1951) was a poor African American woman who died from cancer in 1951 at Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore. Without her consent, cells were taken from her cancerous cervical tumor at the free "colored" ward. These cells were given to a researcher who cultured them and created an immortal cell line used for medical research. The cell lines, called HeLa cells, have not only helped in vital medical research they have also made billions of dollars for the medical research industry.Henrietta's family, however, knew nothing about this cell line and once they learned about the "immortal" and living cell line twenty years after Henrietta's death, they had a multitude of misunderstandings, misgivings, and apprehensions concerning what this meant. They also wondered why there was no compensation provided to the family for these unique cells that were taken from Henrietta. It is an ironic fact that while the HeLa cells have been credited with a myriad of medical advancements, Henrietta's descendents cannot afford health insurance. The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks is a biography about the woman from whom this cell line originated but it also is about her family, racism, class, medical research and medical ethics. The narrative alternates between the personal story of the Lacks family and the scientific history of the HeLa cells. Scientific advancement and discovery is shown along side the darker side of unethical medical practices. The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks has won several awards, including the 2010 Chicago Tribune Heartland Prize for Nonfiction, the 2010 Welcome Trust Book Prize, and the American Association for the Advancement of Science’s Award for Excellence in Science Writing, the 2011 Audie Award for Best Non-Fiction Audiobook, and a Medical Journalists’ Association Open Book Award. Very Highly Recommended - one of the best; http://shetreadssoftly.blogspot.com/

I'm somewhat torn on this book. I feel like there should be two reviews. The first review would say that this book does a great job exposing what happened to Henrietta Lacks, gives a good, brief history of how African Americans have been treated by medical professionals and the racism involved, gives some interesting and thought-provoking background on cell and tissue studies -- what our rights are, what they're not, etc.The second review would say that I'm not entirely sure what to make of Skloot. Yes, she tells a story that needs to be told, but sometimes her methods annoyed me. There were many questions going on in my head while reading this: Is Skloots taking advantage of the Lacks family, in particular Deborah Lacks, for her own gain? How does she differ from other white people who took advantage of the Lacks family? Does setting up a scholarship foundation for them negate all the time she spent harassing them? I mean, good grief, at one point she mentions how she would call Deborah to leave messages on her voice mail every few days for about ten months in an effort to convince Deborah to speak with her. Maybe Skloot gets points for persistence, but, in my book, she gets negative points for harassing someone who obviously didn't want to speak to her. I know journalists can be pretty pushy at times, but I just felt like Skloots crossed some lines by driving past Lacks family houses over and over, repeatedly calling them (not just a few times but every few days for almost a year!). She even admits that some of the brothers were eventually like, "Alright, stop calling us! We'll talk to you!" I don't know about you, but she seems kinda obnoxious.Her descriptions of the Lacks family sometimes border on compassionate and sometimes border on condescending. She often comes across as extremely patronizing when describing Deborah, which bothered me a lot. I'll just stop right there. Two stars because Skloot annoyed me with her obnoxious stalker-like behavior and her condescending tone towards the Lacks family.

"My Expectations Were Too High"Have you ever been totally geeked out about the next greatest book or movie only to feel a let-down when you finally experience it?Conversely, have you ever started a little-known book or movie and felt tremendously and happily surprised when it knocks your socks off?Expectations can be far too influential in my enjoyment of media sometimes.Unfortunately my expectations were too high for this nonfiction book (which won some Goodreads awards in 2010). Admittedly part of the problem is my preference for fiction novels. It was a bit difficult for me to connect to the "characters" involved, particularly the narrator. She's a scientist and a reporter, and I appreciate her intense research and her desire to share the facts, but her style made the story rather dry at times. I felt like I was hit over the head with the irony of mostly white scientists making money off a black woman's cells when her family couldn't afford their own health care. This is a tragic situation and should definitely be explored, but at times the book seemed a bit preachy to me.I'm glad I decided to finish the book because it did improve as it progressed. I enjoyed the scientific and spiritual aspects of the story--why did the HeLa cells survive outside Henrietta Lacks' body when no other cells could? The rationale behind the development of institutional review boards to monitor research ethics was eye-opening. And I chuckled hearing about "Sir Lord Doctor", the swindler "attorney" who tried to get hold of the family's medical records.I'll have to read some glowing reviews by other Goodreads readers, which undoubtedly will shed some light on my understanding of the story. For now I give it 3 stars.

This is a fascinating tale which is relevant to all of our lives. However although I enjoyed the book, I found myself bristling sometimes at the author's continual insertion of herself into the story of Henrietta and other Lacks family members. There is too much about how she first heard about Henrietta Lacks, about how she became intrigued, about how she explored the story, about how she convinced various people to talk to her...there is too much about the framework of how the book came about, which makes for occasionally tedious reading. There is often a self-congratulatory one about much of this, as well as something of a white saviour complex.That said, while I wish there had been less of the above, this is still an incredibly interesting, important story.I think I'll leave the final words to Henrietta's daughter, because she hits the nail on the head:When I go to the doctor for my checkups I always say my mother was HeLa. They get all excited, tell me stuff like how her cells helped make my blood pressure medicines and antidepression pills and how all this important stuff in science happen cause of her. But they don’t never explain more than just sayin, Yeah, your mother was on the moon, she been in nuclear bombs and made that polio vaccine. I really don’t know how she did all that, but I guess I’m glad she did, cause that mean she helpin lots of people. I think she would like that. But I always have thought it was strange, if our mother cells done so much for medicine, how come her family can’t afford to see no doctors? Don’t make no sense.

I picked this book from a community bookshelf in my building. And all because as a science kid, Henrietta Lacks is a known name. But her story isn't.And for that reason, I am so very glad that Rebecca Skloot had taken it upon herself to introduce the person from whom these cells originated. Over the years in my scientific career, I have used hundreds and thousands of passages of HeLa cells, and never stopped to think twice about much else regarding its origin. Mostly because these days, with research, there are so many regulations as to how you go about procuring biological samples; I was unaware that Henrietta Lacks was never asked for her permission. Neither her nor her family have ever been recompensed from the profits companies are making from the sales of the cell line. HeLa cell lines have been used to produce recombinant proteins like insulin, for the creation of vaccines, they have been used in cancer, diabetes, and in all manners of research. These cell lines have also been sent up to the space. You would wonder why? Why her cells? Because it was the only immortalized cell line at the time. Every other cell line would lose viability after a few passages. But not HeLa. And that makes it one of the most valuable tools in the research industry. It was shocking to me to know that Henrietta Lacks' family did not know of all the scientific strides being made until one day someone asked them if they were proud of their mom. This book will have you understand and see how different parties were differently motivated and their feelings about the use of HeLa.

This is a book that I want everyone I know to read. Not only because I 'really liked it' according the definition of a 4-star rating, but because I want everyone to know about Henrietta Lacks and all she has done for likely every human being born after 1951 and I want everyone to know about the author, Rebecca Skloot, who did such a wonderful job telling the story of Henrietta and her Henrietta's family.I learned ALOT from this book about what it was like to be poor, uneducated, and uninformed in the early 1950's and how things have changed since then. Some parts of this book contained scientific and medical information, yet the way the author wrote about it, I never felt bored or that it was written above my comprehension. That in itself was an accomplishment, I thought, for the author. But it goes far beyond that. Ms. Skloot became intrigued by Henrietta Lacks' contribution to the world of science and she tirelessly researched and patiently gained the trust of Henrietta's family, which was not easy to do. The family felt betrayed and only wanted their mother/wife/grandmother to be recognized and known to the world. The author truly had their best interests at heart and wanted the same thing. This book is a personal journey into the lives of an extremely modest family told through a woman who was able to give them all a voice. I hope that many people read the story of this unsung heroine, Ms. Henrietta Lacks.

Part medical history, part cellular biology, and part human interest story, this book raises awareness of the short life of Henrietta Lacks, a black woman with aggressive cancer of the cervix who died in 1951, and how her cancerous cells were preserved, grown, and used to advance medical research. The author explores ethical questions of informed consent and potential uses and abuses of tissue samples. She also shows the impact on the family. As with any book in which the author plays a significant role in the story, there are both benefits and drawbacks. On the plus side, she provides first hand reporting of and insight into the family members’ points of view. On the minus side, her presence occasionally detracts from the compelling storyline, while she digresses into family members hanging up on her or driving around the countryside looking for them. Skloot raises tough questions around such issues as tissue ownership rights, patents for biological material and who should profit from them, family and patient privacy concerns regarding the scientific use of genetic material. Overall, I thought the author did a good job of walking a fine line between the scientific community and the family, attempting to tell both sides in an impartial manner, while allowing the reader to form his or her own opinions. This book certainly provides plentiful “food-for-thought.” Recommended to those interested in medical research, biology, and biographies of remarkable people.

The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks tells three stories: the life of Henrietta Lacks and how cells from her terminal cervical cancer were harvested without her knowledge to create the immortal HeLa line of cells; her family's, particularly her daughter Deborah's, history after her death and their reaction to HeLa; and the author's efforts to track down Henrietta's story and her complicated relationship with Henrietta's family. Not all of these stories are equally compelling. Henrietta's story, and the story of her cells, is fascinating and touches on issues spanning from race to class to scientific ethics that still have an impact today. Unfortunately, the majority of the book is devoted to the author's interactions with Deborah, an erratic and paranoid woman who wears out her welcome long before she runs out of pages. Partly to blame is the book's structure; the author elected to interweave her quest to extract information from Henrietta's family with the information she ultimately gleaned from them. This drains her interactions with the family of any tension, as we already know how things turn out, and forces the author to repeat a lot of information: first when she presents it and later when she discovers it. Overall, the book is a fascinating piece of scientific journalism married unsuccessfully to a memoir and character sketch badly in need of trimming.

You've probably never heard of Henrietta Lacks. I certainly hadn't but after reading this book, like myself, you probably will wish you did. Henrietta's life was short and not very vivid. She was a kind person, and a mother of 5. But at the age of 30, she came down with cervical cancer and gave the doctors of John Hopkins some of her cells. She soon passed away after receiving some awful sounding radiation therapy, and after the cancer spread. Here's the twist: her cells live on to this day. Nicknamed "HeLa," her cells are used in research in any disease imaginable, mainly because unlike most people's cells, they have the unique ability to continue to multiply once leaving the body. The issues....Henrietta didn't know she was giving her cells up for that purpose at the time, which was 1951. IN addition, while her cells are producing millions of dollars for the medical community as they are sold, her living family lives in poverty, and were unaware their mother still existed in some form until many years later. This book is tackled by Skloot and is written so wonderfully. Medical terminology is clearly explained, and she even includes a cast of characters so you don't get the many names mixed up. By the end of this book, I was severely affected by this story, and i highly recommed this book to ANYONE, it is truly an excellent read!

If a doctor has ever removed a mole, an appendix, your tonsils a gallbladder or other organic substances from you, these bits and pieces may not have been immediately incinerated as you believed, but added to millions of other tissue samples already saved for medical research. You're ok with that, right? The world could benefit from a cure for cancer, say. But how would you feel if your pieces were sold around the globe, making profit for unknown persons without your consent or knowledge, while many in your family died early deaths due to a lack of affordable comprehensive health care. Rebecca Skloot shines a light on this issue in The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks, a non-fiction book that reads like a novel. Actually, more like two novels: 1. The unlikely case of Henrietta Lacks, whose cancerous cervical cells have been living, reproducing and advancing medical science for many decades and 2. Skloot's 10-year story about the "making of the book" and her relationship with the Lacks family, particularly Henrietta's daughter, Rebecca, a lovable character no-one could have concocted. The settings-Johns Hopkins Hospital, the former Crownsville Hospital for the Negro Insane and several tiny Virginia towns became the focus of fascinating subplots as well.

What a book! I don't know what took me so long to read The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks. Part history, part science, it is an unforgettable story about science and American racial history.HeLa cell line is the first human cell line that grow in culture indefinitely. It was originally taken from a black American woman called Henrietta Lacks who was diagnosed with and died of cervical cancer. HeLa cells have helped scientists all over the world to make crucial scientific discoveries from polio vaccination, cancer research, to IVF, gene editing and many many more.This book took the author 10 years to finish. Chapters iterate between the life of Henrietta Lacks and her family, and HeLa's contribution in scientific research. I am sympathetic to the family, who felt wronged. Their mother's cells were taken without consent. No one notified the family until 25 years later when a scientist wanted their blood to do more research. The financial gain from the cell line did not benefit the family at all. It's a complicated situation. Racial divide and injustice caused and reinforced by misunderstanding and distrust. It's a shock to me that even to this day, no law governs how human tissues should be used.

Finished this book last night.I did not know beforehand what this book would be about so when I started reading about cells and tissue matter and cancer I thought to myself. O no, This is not a book for me! The next morning I woke up and felt a pain and immediately thought "do I have cancer?" Yes I am a bit of a hypochondriac, I admit it. lol.Anyways, I did find it very interesting cause I had the worst biology teacher ever (or maybe it was me come to think of it, worst pupil?) and do not know much about that subject.After reading half I did have a bit of a How shall I call it, not really wanting to read more cause I did not really like the way the family of Henriette acted in the book but I am glad I read on. I've learned a lot and even though it appears these people seemingly always shout, I see the good in them and understand now better how hard it was for them to find out.The questions at the end of the book are intriguing and I am planning to google more about tissue donation, the law about that , Hela cells and the likes. So after all I am not regretting having bought this book.

The history of HeLa and Henrietta Lacks is one that should never be forgotten, but sadly almost every scientist knows about HeLa, but very few know who Henrietta Lacks was. Her story should be more widely known than what it is today, she deserves that credit. HeLa truly revolutionized the world of science and medicine, but at what cost? Where do we draw the lines for right or wrong? It’s a book that inspires so many questions about ethics and morals, and some of them don’t have an easy answer or solution. But what is clear is this: without Henrietta Lacks and HeLa, we wouldn’t have the medical care and cures we have today and she deserves to be remembered as a human being, and not just for her remarkable cells.

I was most surprised to learn that HeLa cells went to the moon! It astonishes me how far researchers go to discover what can be learned and accomplished. It is amazing that a microscopic piece of an abnormal growth can do so much. How ironic that a cell which multiplied so rapidly and killed a woman, is used to save the lives of millions of people. I don't really have a scientific mind and prior to reading this book never gave a second thought about the process of medicinal breakthroughs. I have developed a new respect for cancer cell research.Henrietta's story was filled with sadness and hardship … handed down from one generation to the next. My heart broke for her daughter Elsie and the terrible treatment she received at the asylum she was sent to when her mother fell sick. The surviving Lacks children felt cheated and incomplete without their mother. But when Rebecca Skloot brought to light the story behind HeLa cells, her family gained some sense of dignity despite the suffering they all endured.

Amazing book based on subject matter and very well written. The author spent many years researching and countless hours interviewing. She has given us the incredible story of Henrietta Lacks and heartbreaking story of her family. She has also touched on issues within the medical community, scientific research, big pharma, government oversite (or lack thereof), and asks the questions "who owns our cells, who can take them, and who can profit from them". I loved the way the author heads each chapter with a timeline so we know where we are in history and I could relate to it because it happened within my lifetime. Since this all started back in 1951, I can see where people would think race was an issue and it was. However, I believe it's also a case of the educated versus the uneducated. It's a tragic story, but so much good has come from what happened. Based on what I've read, almost everyone has benefited from Henrietta Lacks.

Both informative and captivating, this surprising nonfiction book reads like a really catchy novel and you have to remind yourself from time to time that it’s all too real as it is tragic. Skloot’s writing brings Henrietta Lacks and her family to life, from her ancestors to her children, the way it was told to her, whether some of the facts were verified or not.My only objection is that Skloot seems to subtly make herself some sort of hero figure in this book, where her growing friendship with Henrietta's daughter, Deborah, portrayed in the second half, sidelines the story of the HeLa cells, the science and the ethics behind it. It takes a rather voyeuristic turn for the sake of a little more drama added to an already heartbreaking story. It was quite uncomfortable to read and not particularly the place of a journalist to constantly highlight how she got certain aspects of the story.

This is an absolute must-read about the evolution of medical ethics over the last 75 years, told through the story of one family. The cells of Henrietta Lacks did so much more than help advance medical science, it helped us find humanity when it lost its way, and negotiate 'virtues' in a market-driven society. Now we speak about mixing commercialization with conscience where once the two did not jell very well. Rebecca Skloot's unrelenting pursuit of Lacks' story is both inspiring and sobering. She makes us peel back the layers of scientific advancement all the way down to the humans lodged in the pip that holds the material for the next generation. She pricks it with compunction and makes them burst out into the world that they helped create, so that we may change it by accepting that the spirit of science is us, is them, is Henrietta Lacks.

Listened to the audiobook on a ten-hour drive, and it was so good, I could have kept driving just to hear the last two hours. This is nonfiction but it's so well crafted it reads like fiction. I found the science aspect fascinating and the social aspects heartbreaking. The book brings up the interesting question of whether one has the right to weigh in on how their removed tissues are used or whether the removed tissues become the 'property' of the doctors and hospitals that remove them. I read (listened to...) this both as a medical professional but also a daughter, which allowed me to consider it from both angles. I found it thoroughly engrossing.

I starting reading this without knowing what it was about, and it's a real doozy. It's about a woman who's cells are responsible for much of our medicines and medical knowledge of today. I guess the topic is bioethics. Her background and the life of her family after her death are given. There's so much moral conflict surround their situation and no clear cut answers for these situations going forward. The author does a great job of showing all sides of the matter. Very interesting and thought provoking. I liked learning about the people involved, putting the human elements into the equation.

Wow, what audacity, and what hubris, to merely use a person's bodily components without permission, and indeed, apparently in spite of withheld permision, simply because the patient was on the public ward, and thus did not have to pay for treatment, acccording to the doctors who had no clue about the life, circumstances, nor even the proper name of the patient. How outrageous. Many thanks to this biology student who never lost her curiosity, and in becoming a medical journalist, followed the trail of a woman whose cells, according to her daughter, refused to be left in ignorant silence. Good work.

I just re-read this book for my book group. It is so full of interesting ideas, tragedy, and moral murk that I hope we get a good turn out. I feel so badly for the Lacks family and the way that they were taken advantage of time and again. And it kind of delivers home the incredible hubris of some in the scientific establishment, but also the power of discovery and the ways that technology has led to fantastic leaps in understanding.7/2010SUCH A GOOD BOOK! When it comes out in paperback, this is a MUST for Pageturners.

Wow. I finished this book last night and decided I better sleep on it before I write this. No doubt, this is a powerful book about a fascinating piece of scientific history. Really understanding the impact of these cells is a bit overwhelming. This book had me alternating between absolute highs, where the author captured some truly tender moments with the family, and lows where she exposed unethical medical practices. I'm glad this story got told. It's important one, and a sad one. I know this book will stay with me for a long time. I will recommend it to everyone I know.
